   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">

   </h1>

    </div>

          (2011
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2011-nationality_2-0">

           </a>
          </sup>
          )
         </span>
        </th>
        <td>
         <div class="plainlist">
          <ul>
           <li>

            <a href="/wiki/Croats" title="Croats">
             Croats
            </a>
           </li>

            4.36%
            <a href="/wiki/Serbs_of_Croatia" title="Serbs of Croatia">

            </a>

            <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Croatia#Ethnic_groups" title="Demographics of Croatia">
             others
            </a>
           </li>

      <p>
       <b>
        Croatia
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="'k' in 'kind'">
            k
           </span>
           <span title="'r' in 'rye'">
            r
           </span>
           <span title="/oʊ/: 'o' in 'code'">
            oʊ
           </span>
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">
            eɪ
           </span>
           <span title="/ʃ/: 'sh' in 'shy'">
            ʃ
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Croatia.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/24/En-us-Croatia.ogg" title="En-us-Croatia.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key">
        <i title="English pronunciation respelling">
         kroh-
         <span style="font-size:90%">
          AY
         </span>
         -shə
        </i>
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="hr">
         Hrvatska
        </span>
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian" title="Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian">
         [xř̩ʋaːtskaː]
        </a>
       </span>
       ), officially the
       <b>
        Republic of Croatia
       </b>
       (Croatian:
       <i>
        <span lang="hr">
         Republika Hrvatska
        </span>
       </i>
       ,
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Hr-Republika_Hrvatska.oga" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/33/Hr-Republika_Hrvatska.oga" title="Hr-Republika Hrvatska.oga">
          listen
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">
         (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           help
          </span>
         </a>
         ·
         <a href="/wiki/File:Hr-Republika_Hrvatska.oga" title="File:Hr-Republika Hrvatska.oga">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           info
          </span>
         </a>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ), is a country situated at the crossroads of
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
        Central
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">
        Southeast Europe
       </a>
       , on the
       <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
        Adriatic Sea
       </a>
       . Its capital city is
       <a href="/wiki/Zagreb" title="Zagreb">
        Zagreb
       </a>
       , which forms one of the country's
       <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Croatia" title="Administrative divisions of Croatia">
        primary subdivisions
       </a>
       , along with its
       <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Croatia" title="Counties of Croatia">
        twenty counties
       </a>
       . Croatia has a total area of 56,594 square kilometres (21,851 square miles) and a population of 4.28 million, most of whom are
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
        Roman Catholics
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The Croats arrived in the area of present-day Croatia during the early part of the 7th century
       <a href="/wiki/Anno_Domini" title="Anno Domini">
        AD
       </a>
       . They organised the state into two duchies by the 9th century.
       <a href="/wiki/Tomislav_of_Croatia" title="Tomislav of Croatia">
        Tomislav
       </a>
       became the first king by 925, elevating Croatia to the status of a kingdom. The
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(925%E2%80%931102)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)">
        Kingdom of Croatia
       </a>
       retained its sovereignty for nearly two centuries, reaching its peak during the rule of Kings
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_Kre%C5%A1imir_IV_of_Croatia" title="Peter Krešimir IV of Croatia">
        Petar Krešimir IV
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Demetrius_Zvonimir_of_Croatia" title="Demetrius Zvonimir of Croatia">
        Dmitar Zvonimir
       </a>
       . Croatia entered a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatia_in_the_union_with_Hungary" title="Croatia in the union with Hungary">
        personal union
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">
        Hungary
       </a>
       in 1102. In 1527, faced with
       <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Years%27_Croatian%E2%80%93Ottoman_War" title="Hundred Years' Croatian–Ottoman War">
        Ottoman conquest
       </a>
       , the Croatian Parliament elected
       <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor">
        Ferdinand I
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">
        House of Habsburg
       </a>
       to the Croatian throne. During the early 19th century, parts of the country were split into the
       <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_Provinces" title="Illyrian Provinces">
        French Illyrian Provinces
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
        Austria-Hungary
       </a>
       occupied its Bosnia and Herzegovina side–a dispute settled by the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Berlin_(1878)" title="Treaty of Berlin (1878)">
        1878 Treaty of Berlin
       </a>
       . In 1918, after
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        World War I
       </a>
       , Croatia was included in the unrecognized
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Slovenes,_Croats_and_Serbs" title="State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs">
        State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs
       </a>
       which seceded from
       <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
        Austria-Hungary
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Creation_of_Yugoslavia" title="Creation of Yugoslavia">
        merged into
       </a>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Kingdom of Yugoslavia">
        Kingdom of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       . A
       <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">
        fascist Croatian puppet state
       </a>
       backed by Fascist Italy and Nazi Germany existed in
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       . After the war, Croatia became a founding member and a federal constituent of the
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">
        Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       , a constitutionally
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">
        socialist state
       </a>
       . On 25 June 1991, Croatia
       <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Croatia" title="Independence of Croatia">
        declared independence
       </a>
       , which came wholly into effect on 8 October of the same year. The
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence" title="Croatian War of Independence">
        Croatian War of Independence
       </a>
       was fought successfully for four years following the declaration.
      </p>
      <p>
       Croatia is a
       <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">
        republic
       </a>
       governed under a
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
        parliamentary system
       </a>
       and a
       <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">
        developed country
       </a>
       with a
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">
        very high standard of living
       </a>
       . A
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">
        middle power
       </a>
       in international relations, it is a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       (EU),
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       (UN), the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
        Council of Europe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">
        World Trade Organization
       </a>
       (WTO) and a founding member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Union_for_the_Mediterranean" title="Union for the Mediterranean">
        Union for the Mediterranean
       </a>
       . As an active participant in the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping" title="United Nations peacekeeping">
        UN peacekeeping forces
       </a>
       , Croatia has contributed troops to the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">
        NATO-led mission in Afghanistan
       </a>
       and took a non-permanent seat on the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">
        UN Security Council
       </a>
       for the 2008–2009 term. Since 2000, the Croatian government has constantly invested in infrastructure, especially
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Croatia" title="Transport in Croatia">
        transport routes and facilities
       </a>
       along the
       <a href="/wiki/Pan-European_corridors" title="Pan-European corridors">
        Pan-European corridors
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Service_sector" title="Service sector">
        service sector
       </a>
       dominates Croatia's economy, followed by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrial_sector" title="Industrial sector">
        industrial sector
       </a>
       and agriculture.
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Croatia" title="Tourism in Croatia">
        International tourism
       </a>
       is a significant source of revenue during the summer, with Croatia ranked the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">
        18th most popular
       </a>
       tourist destination in the world. The state controls a part of the economy, with substantial government expenditure. The European Union is Croatia's most important
       <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">
        trading partner
       </a>
       . Internal sources produce a significant portion of
       <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Croatia" title="Energy in Croatia">
        energy in Croatia
       </a>
       . Croatia provides a
       <a href="/wiki/Social_security" title="Social security">
        social security
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Croatia" title="Healthcare in Croatia">
        universal health care
       </a>
       system, and a tuition-free
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Croatia" title="Education in Croatia">
        primary and secondary education
       </a>
       , while supporting
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Croatia" title="Culture of Croatia">
        culture
       </a>
       through numerous public institutions and corporate investments in
       <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Croatia" title="Media of Croatia">
        media
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_literature" title="Croatian literature">
        publishing
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>

      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Croatia" title="Name of Croatia">
        Name of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Greda_i_zabat_s_natpisom_kneza_Branimira_879.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="421" data-file-width="1000" height="93" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Greda_i_zabat_s_natpisom_kneza_Branimira_879.jpg/220px-Greda_i_zabat_s_natpisom_kneza_Branimira_879.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Greda_i_zabat_s_natpisom_kneza_Branimira_879.jpg/330px-Greda_i_zabat_s_natpisom_kneza_Branimira_879.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Greda_i_zabat_s_natpisom_kneza_Branimira_879.jpg/440px-Greda_i_zabat_s_natpisom_kneza_Branimira_879.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Greda_i_zabat_s_natpisom_kneza_Branimira_879.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Branimir_Inscription" title="Branimir Inscription">
          Branimir Inscription
         </a>
         is the oldest preserved monument containing an inscription defining a Croatian medieval ruler as a duke of Croats
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Croatia" title="Name of Croatia">
        name of Croatia
       </a>
       derives from
       <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">
        Medieval Latin
       </a>
       <i>
        Croātia
       </i>
       . Compare
       <i>
        DUX CRUATORVM
       </i>
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Sic" title="Sic">
         sic
        </a>
       </i>
       ] ("Duke of the Croats") attested in the
       <a href="/wiki/Branimir_inscription" title="Branimir inscription">
        Branimir inscription
       </a>
       . Itself a derivation of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North-West_Slavic" title="North-West Slavic">
        North-West Slavic
       </a>
       <i>
        *Xrovat-
       </i>
       , by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liquid_metathesis" title="Liquid metathesis">
        liquid metathesis
       </a>
       from proposed
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_Slavic" title="Common Slavic">
        Common Slavic
       </a>
       period
       <i>
        <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/xorvat%D1%8A" title="wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/xorvatъ">
         *
         <i>
          Xorvat
         </i>
        </a>
       </i>
       , from proposed
       <a href="/wiki/Proto-Slavic" title="Proto-Slavic">
        Proto-Slavic
       </a>
       <i>
        *Xŭrvatŭ
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        *Xъrvatъ
       </i>
       ) which possibly comes from
       <a href="/wiki/Old_Persian" title="Old Persian">
        Old Persian
       </a>
       <i>
        *xaraxwat-
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gluhak-1993_9-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gluhak-1993-9">
         [8]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The word is attested by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_Iranian" title="Old Iranian">
        Old Iranian
       </a>
       toponym
       <i>
        Harahvait-
       </i>
       which is the native name of
       <a href="/wiki/Arachosia" title="Arachosia">
        Arachosia
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The origin of the name is uncertain, but is thought to be a
       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_language" title="Gothic language">
        Gothic
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">
        Indo-Aryan
       </a>
       term assigned to a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slavic_peoples" title="Slavic peoples">
        Slavic tribe
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KU-Greenberg_10-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-KU-Greenberg-10">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The oldest preserved record of the Croatian
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">
        ethnonym
       </a>
       *xъrvatъ is of variable stem, attested in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet" title="Baška tablet">
        Baška tablet
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Style_(manner_of_address)" title="Style (manner of address)">
        style
       </a>
       <i>
        zvъnъmirъ kralъ xrъvatъskъ
       </i>
       ("
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dmitar_Zvonimir" title="Dmitar Zvonimir">
        Zvonimir
       </a>
       , Croatian king").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fučić-1971_11-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Fučić-1971-11">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The first attestation of the Latin term is attributed to a charter of Duke
       <a href="/wiki/Trpimir_I_of_Croatia" title="Trpimir I of Croatia">
        Trpimir
       </a>
       from the year 852. The original is lost, and just a 1568 copy is preserved, leading to doubts over the authenticity of the claim.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić200727_12-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić200727-12">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The oldest preserved stone inscription is the 9th-century Branimir Inscription found near
       <a href="/wiki/Benkovac" title="Benkovac">
        Benkovac
       </a>
       , where Duke
       <a href="/wiki/Branimir_of_Croatia" title="Branimir of Croatia">
        Branimir
       </a>
       is styled as
       <i>
        Dux Cruatorvm
       </i>
       . The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inscription" title="Inscription">
        inscription
       </a>
       is not believed to be dated accurately, but is likely to be from during the period of 879–892, during Branimir's rule.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007195–198_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007195–198-13">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="quotebox pullquote" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em; width:23em; padding: 10px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 90%; background-color: #E5E4E2;">
       <div class="" style="background-color: #E5E4E2; color: black; text-align: center; font-size: larger; font-weight: bold;">

       </div>

              <span class="flagicon">

              </span>
              <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">
               Yugoslavia
              </a>
             </i>
             (1945–1990)
            </li>
           </ul>
          </div>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="flagicon">
             <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="4000" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Flag_of_Croatia_%281990%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Croatia_%281990%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Flag_of_Croatia_%281990%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_Croatia_%281990%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Flag_of_Croatia_%281990%29.svg/46px-Flag_of_Croatia_%281990%29.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
            </span>
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_Croatia" title="Republic of Croatia">
             Republic of Croatia
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
          <div class="plainlist" style="margin-left: 1.6em;">
           <ul>
            <li>
             <i>
              democratic republic within
              <span class="flagicon">
               <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="600" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Flag_of_SFR_Yugoslavia.svg/23px-Flag_of_SFR_Yugoslavia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Flag_of_SFR_Yugoslavia.svg/35px-Flag_of_SFR_Yugoslavia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Flag_of_SFR_Yugoslavia.svg/46px-Flag_of_SFR_Yugoslavia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
              </span>
              <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">
               Yugoslavia
              </a>
             </i>
             (1990–1991)
            </li>
           </ul>
          </div>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="flagicon">
             <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Croatia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Croatia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Croatia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Croatia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Croatia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Croatia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
            </span>
            <a class="mw-selflink selflink">
             Croatia
            </a>
            (1991–present)
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Croatia" title="History of Croatia">
        History of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_antiquity">
        Prehistory and antiquity
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Croatia_before_the_Croats" title="History of Croatia before the Croats">
        History of Croatia before the Croats
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The area known as Croatia today was inhabited throughout the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prehistoric_period" title="Prehistoric period">
        prehistoric period
       </a>
       . Fossils of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neanderthals" title="Neanderthals">
        Neanderthals
       </a>
       dating to the middle
       <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">
        Palaeolithic
       </a>
       period have been unearthed in northern Croatia, with the most famous and the best presented site in
       <a href="/wiki/Krapina" title="Krapina">
        Krapina
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Remnants of several
       <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
        Neolithic
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">
        Chalcolithic
       </a>
       cultures were found in all regions of the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The largest proportion of the sites is in the river valleys of northern Croatia, and the most significant cultures whose presence was discovered include
       <a href="/wiki/Star%C4%8Devo_culture" title="Starčevo culture">
        Starčevo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vu%C4%8Dedol_culture" title="Vučedol culture">
        Vučedol
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Baden_culture" title="Baden culture">
        Baden cultures
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">
        Iron Age
       </a>
       left traces of the early Illyrian
       <a href="/wiki/Hallstatt_culture" title="Hallstatt culture">
        Hallstatt culture
       </a>
       and the Celtic
       <a href="/wiki/La_T%C3%A8ne_culture" title="La Tène culture">
        La Tène culture
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Greek_and_Roman_rule">
        Greek and Roman rule
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Illyria" title="Illyria">
        Illyria
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia_(Roman_province)" title="Dalmatia (Roman province)">
        Dalmatia (Roman province)
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tanais_Tablet_B.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="595" data-file-width="414" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Tanais_Tablet_B.png/130px-Tanais_Tablet_B.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Tanais_Tablet_B.png/195px-Tanais_Tablet_B.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Tanais_Tablet_B.png/260px-Tanais_Tablet_B.png 2x" width="130"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tanais_Tablet_B.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Tanais_Tablets" title="Tanais Tablets">
          Tanais Tablet B
         </a>
         , name
         <i>
          Khoroáthos
         </i>
         highlighted
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Much later, the region was settled by
       <a href="/wiki/Liburnians" title="Liburnians">
        Liburnians
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Illyrians" title="Illyrians">
        Illyrians
       </a>
       , while the first Greek colonies were established on the islands of
       <a href="/wiki/Kor%C4%8Dula" title="Korčula">
        Korčula
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hvar" title="Hvar">
        Hvar
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vis_(island)" title="Vis (island)">
        Vis
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 9 AD the territory of today's Croatia became part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire
       </a>
       . Emperor
       <a href="/wiki/Diocletian" title="Diocletian">
        Diocletian
       </a>
       built a
       <a href="/wiki/Diocletian%27s_Palace" title="Diocletian's Palace">
        large palace
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Split,_Croatia" title="Split, Croatia">
        Split
       </a>
       when he retired in AD 305.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       During the 5th century, one of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Concise_list_of_Roman_emperors#Western_Roman_Empire" title="Concise list of Roman emperors">
        last Emperors of the Western Roman Empire
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Julius_Nepos" title="Julius Nepos">
        Julius Nepos
       </a>
       , ruled his small empire from the palace.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The period ends with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avars_(Carpathians)" title="Avars (Carpathians)">
        Avar
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Croats" title="Croats">
        Croat
       </a>
       invasions in the first half of the 7th century and destruction of almost all Roman towns. Roman survivors retreated to more favourable sites on the coast, islands and mountains. The city of
       <a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik" title="Dubrovnik">
        Dubrovnik
       </a>
       was founded by such survivors from
       <a href="/wiki/Epidaurum" title="Epidaurum">
        Epidaurum
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AAPatton_23-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AAPatton-23">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnogenesis" title="Ethnogenesis">
        ethnogenesis
       </a>
       of Croats is uncertain and there are several competing theories,
       <i>
        Slavic
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Iranian
       </i>
       being the most frequently put forward. The most widely accepted of these, the
       <i>
        Slavic
       </i>
       theory, proposes migration of
       <a href="/wiki/White_Croats" title="White Croats">
        White Croats
       </a>
       from the territory of
       <a href="/wiki/White_Croatia" title="White Croatia">
        White Croatia
       </a>
       during the
       <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">
        Migration Period
       </a>
       . Conversely, the
       <i>
        Iranian
       </i>
       theory proposes
       <a href="/wiki/Iranian_peoples" title="Iranian peoples">
        Iranian
       </a>
       origin, based on
       <a href="/wiki/Tanais_Tablets" title="Tanais Tablets">
        Tanais Tablets
       </a>
       containing
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">
        Greek
       </a>
       inscription of given names
       <i>
        Χορούαθ[ος]
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        Χοροάθος
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        Χορόαθος
       </i>
       (Khoroúathos, Khoroáthos, and Khoróathos) and their interpretation as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anthroponym" title="Anthroponym">
        anthroponyms
       </a>
       of Croatian people.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nikšić-Heršak_24-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Nikšić-Heršak-24">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Croatia" title="Duchy of Croatia">
        Duchy of Croatia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(925%E2%80%931102)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)">
        Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(1102%E2%80%931526)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (1102–1526)">
        Kingdom of Croatia (1102–1526)
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa" title="Republic of Ragusa">
        Republic of Ragusa
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oton_Ivekovic,_Dolazak_Hrvata_na_Jadran.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="743" data-file-width="1099" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Dolazak_Hrvata_na_Jadran.jpg/220px-Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Dolazak_Hrvata_na_Jadran.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Dolazak_Hrvata_na_Jadran.jpg/330px-Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Dolazak_Hrvata_na_Jadran.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Dolazak_Hrvata_na_Jadran.jpg/440px-Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Dolazak_Hrvata_na_Jadran.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oton_Ivekovic,_Dolazak_Hrvata_na_Jadran.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Arrival of the
         <a href="/wiki/Croats" title="Croats">
          Croats
         </a>
         at the
         <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
          Adriatic Sea
         </a>
         , painting by
         <a href="/wiki/Oton_Ivekovi%C4%87" title="Oton Iveković">
          Oton Iveković
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Balkans925.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="605" data-file-width="472" height="282" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Balkans925.png/220px-Balkans925.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Balkans925.png/330px-Balkans925.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Balkans925.png/440px-Balkans925.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Balkans925.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(925%E2%80%931102)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)">
          Kingdom of Croatia
         </a>
         c. 925, during the reign of King Tomislav
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to the work
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/De_Administrando_Imperio" title="De Administrando Imperio">
         De Administrando Imperio
        </a>
       </i>
       written by the 10th-century Byzantine Emperor
       <a href="/wiki/Constantine_VII" title="Constantine VII">
        Constantine VII
       </a>
       , the Croats had arrived in what is today Croatia in the early 7th century; however, that claim is disputed and competing hypotheses date the event between the 6th and the 9th centuries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007249–293_25-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007249–293-25">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Eventually two
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dukedom_(administrative_division)" title="Dukedom (administrative division)">
        dukedoms
       </a>
       were formed—
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pannonian_Croatia" title="Pannonian Croatia">
        Duchy of Pannonia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Croatia" title="Duchy of Croatia">
        Duchy of Croatia
       </a>
       , ruled by
       <a href="/wiki/Ljudevit" title="Ljudevit">
        Ljudevit
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Borna_(duke)" title="Borna (duke)">
        Borna
       </a>
       , as attested by chronicles of
       <a href="/wiki/Einhard" title="Einhard">
        Einhard
       </a>
       starting in 818. The record represents the first document of Croatian realms,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vassal_states" title="Vassal states">
        vassal states
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">
        Francia
       </a>
       at the time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007157–160_26-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007157–160-26">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="502" data-file-width="960" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.jpg/220px-Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.jpg/330px-Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.jpg/440px-Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet" title="Baška tablet">
          Baška tablet
         </a>
         , the oldest evidence of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Glagolitic_alphabet" title="Glagolitic alphabet">
          glagolitic script
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Frankish overlordship ended during the reign of
       <a href="/wiki/Mislav_of_Croatia" title="Mislav of Croatia">
        Mislav
       </a>
       two decades later.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007169–170_27-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007169–170-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the Constantine VII
       <a href="/wiki/Christianization" title="Christianization">
        Christianization
       </a>
       of Croats began in the 7th century, but the claim is disputed and generally Christianization is associated with the 9th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The first native Croatian ruler recognised by the Pope was Duke Branimir, who received papal recognition from
       <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_VIII" title="Pope John VIII">
        Pope John VIII
       </a>
       on 7 June 879.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007195–198_13-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007195–198-13">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Tomislav_of_Croatia" title="Tomislav of Croatia">
        Tomislav
       </a>
       was the first ruler of Croatia who was styled a king in a letter from the
       <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_X" title="Pope John X">
        Pope John X
       </a>
       , dating kingdom of Croatia to year 925. Tomislav defeated Hungarian and
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian%E2%80%93Bulgarian_battle_of_926" title="Croatian–Bulgarian battle of 926">
        Bulgarian invasions
       </a>
       , spreading the influence of Croatian kings.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Posavec_29-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Posavec-29">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The medieval Croatian kingdom reached its peak in the 11th century during the reigns of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Petar_Kre%C5%A1imir_IV_of_Croatia" title="Petar Krešimir IV of Croatia">
        Petar Krešimir IV
       </a>
       (1058–1074) and
       <a href="/wiki/Demetrius_Zvonimir_of_Croatia" title="Demetrius Zvonimir of Croatia">
        Dmitar Zvonimir
       </a>
       (1075–1089).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Margetić_30-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Margetić-30">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       When
       <a href="/wiki/Stephen_II_of_Croatia" title="Stephen II of Croatia">
        Stjepan II
       </a>
       died in 1091 ending the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/House_of_Trpimirovi%C4%87" title="House of Trpimirović">
        Trpimirović
       </a>
       dynasty,
       <a href="/wiki/Ladislaus_I_of_Hungary" title="Ladislaus I of Hungary">
        Ladislaus I of Hungary
       </a>
       claimed the Croatian crown in name of his sister
       <a href="/wiki/Helena_of_Hungary,_Queen_of_Croatia" title="Helena of Hungary, Queen of Croatia">
        Helena
       </a>
       , wife of King Dmitar Zvonimir. Opposition to the claim led to a
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gvozd_Mountain" title="Battle of Gvozd Mountain">
        war
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatia_in_personal_union_with_Hungary" title="Croatia in personal union with Hungary">
        personal union of Croatia and Hungary
       </a>
       in 1102, ruled by
       <a href="/wiki/Coloman,_King_of_Hungary" title="Coloman, King of Hungary">
        Coloman
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HR-HU-Heka_31-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HR-HU-Heka-31">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       For the next four centuries, the Kingdom of Croatia was ruled by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sabor" title="Sabor">
        Sabor
       </a>
       (parliament) and a
       <a href="/wiki/Ban_of_Croatia" title="Ban of Croatia">
        Ban
       </a>
       (viceroy) appointed by the king.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Povijest-saborovanja_32-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Povijest-saborovanja-32">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The period saw increasing threat of
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman
       </a>
       conquest and struggle against the
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">
        Republic of Venice
       </a>
       for control of coastal areas. The Venetians gained control over most of Dalmatia by 1428, with exception of the
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa" title="Republic of Ragusa">
        city-state of Dubrovnik
       </a>
       which became independent.
       <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Years%27_Croatian%E2%80%93Ottoman_War" title="Hundred Years' Croatian–Ottoman War">
        Ottoman conquests
       </a>
       led to the 1493
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Krbava_field" title="Battle of Krbava field">
        Battle of Krbava field
       </a>
       and 1526
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Moh%C3%A1cs" title="Battle of Mohács">
        Battle of Mohács
       </a>
       , both ending in decisive Ottoman victories. King
       <a href="/wiki/Louis_II_of_Hungary" title="Louis II of Hungary">
        Louis II
       </a>
       died at Mohács, and in 1527, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1527_election_in_Cetin" title="1527 election in Cetin">
        Croatian Parliament met in Cetin
       </a>
       and chose Ferdinand I of the
       <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">
        House of Habsburg
       </a>
       as new ruler of Croatia, under the condition that he provide protection to Croatia against the Ottoman Empire while respecting its political rights.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Povijest-saborovanja_32-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Povijest-saborovanja-32">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_33-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-33">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This period saw the rise of influential nobility such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Frankopan" title="Frankopan">
        Frankopan
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zrinski" title="Zrinski">
        Zrinski
       </a>
       families to prominence and ultimately numerous Bans from the two families.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Font_34-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Font-34">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Habsburg_Monarchy_and_Austria-Hungary_.281538.E2.80.931918.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Habsburg_Monarchy_and_Austria-Hungary_(1538–1918)">
        Habsburg Monarchy and Austria-Hungary (1538–1918)
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(Habsburg)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)">
        Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatian%E2%80%93Ottoman_Wars" title="Croatian–Ottoman Wars">
        Croatian–Ottoman Wars
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
        Austria-Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Following the decisive Ottoman victories, Croatia was split into civilian and military territories, with the partition formed in 1538. The military territories would become known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Military_Frontier" title="Croatian Military Frontier">
        Croatian Military Frontier
       </a>
       and were under direct Imperial control. Ottoman advances in the Croatian territory continued until the 1593
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sisak" title="Battle of Sisak">
        Battle of Sisak
       </a>
       , the first decisive Ottoman defeat, and stabilisation of borders.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_33-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-33">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1663" data-file-width="2306" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg/220px-Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg/330px-Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg/440px-Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Croatian
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Ban_of_Croatia" title="Ban of Croatia">
           ban
          </a>
         </i>
         <a href="/wiki/Nikola_%C5%A0ubi%C4%87_Zrinski" title="Nikola Šubić Zrinski">
          Nikola Šubić Zrinski
         </a>
         is honored as a national hero both in Croatia and in Hungary for his defense of
         <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Szigetv%C3%A1r" title="Siege of Szigetvár">
          Szigetvár
         </a>
         against the
         <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_wars_in_Europe" title="Ottoman wars in Europe">
          invading Ottoman Turks
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Turkish_War" title="Great Turkish War">
        Great Turkish War
       </a>
       (1683–1698),
       <a href="/wiki/Slavonia" title="Slavonia">
        Slavonia
       </a>
       was regained but western
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosnia" title="Bosnia">
        Bosnia
       </a>
       , which had been part of Croatia before the Ottoman conquest, remained outside Croatian control.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_33-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-33">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The present-day border between the two countries is a remnant of this outcome.
       <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">
        Dalmatia
       </a>
       , the southern part of the border, was similarly defined by the
       <a href="/wiki/Cretan_War_(1645%E2%80%931669)" title="Cretan War (1645–1669)">
        Fifth
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Venetian_War_(1714%E2%80%931718)" title="Ottoman–Venetian War (1714–1718)">
        Seventh Ottoman–Venetian Wars
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELane1973409_35-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELane1973409-35">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Austria-Hungary_map.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="605" data-file-width="783" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Austria-Hungary_map.svg/220px-Austria-Hungary_map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Austria-Hungary_map.svg/330px-Austria-Hungary_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Austria-Hungary_map.svg/440px-Austria-Hungary_map.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Austria-Hungary_map.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia-Slavonia" title="Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia">
          Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia
         </a>
         (no. 17) was autonomous kingdom within
         <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
          Austria-Hungary
         </a>
         created in 1868 following the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatian-Hungarian_Settlement" title="Croatian-Hungarian Settlement">
          Croatian-Hungarian Settlement
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ivan_Zasche,_Portret_bana_Josipa_Jelacica.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="979" data-file-width="708" height="263" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Ivan_Zasche%2C_Portret_bana_Josipa_Jelacica.jpg/190px-Ivan_Zasche%2C_Portret_bana_Josipa_Jelacica.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Ivan_Zasche%2C_Portret_bana_Josipa_Jelacica.jpg/285px-Ivan_Zasche%2C_Portret_bana_Josipa_Jelacica.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Ivan_Zasche%2C_Portret_bana_Josipa_Jelacica.jpg/380px-Ivan_Zasche%2C_Portret_bana_Josipa_Jelacica.jpg 2x" width="190"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ivan_Zasche,_Portret_bana_Josipa_Jelacica.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ban
         <a href="/wiki/Josip_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Josip Jelačić">
          Josip Jelačić
         </a>
         fought
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1848">
          Hungarians in 1848 and 1849
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatian%E2%80%93Ottoman_Wars" title="Croatian–Ottoman Wars">
        Ottoman wars
       </a>
       instigated great demographic changes. Croats migrated towards
       <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">
        Austria
       </a>
       and the present-day
       <a href="/wiki/Burgenland_Croats" title="Burgenland Croats">
        Burgenland Croats
       </a>
       are direct descendants of these settlers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       To replace the fleeing population, the Habsburgs encouraged the Christian populations of Bosnia and
       <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">
        Serbia
       </a>
       to provide military service in the Croatian Military Frontier. Serb migration into this region peaked during the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Serb_Migrations" title="Great Serb Migrations">
        Great Serb Migrations
       </a>
       of 1690 and 1737–39.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Parliament" title="Croatian Parliament">
        Croatian Parliament
       </a>
       supported
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emperor_Charles_VI" title="Emperor Charles VI">
        King Charles III
       </a>
       's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pragmatic_Sanction" title="Pragmatic Sanction">
        Pragmatic Sanction
       </a>
       and signed their own
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pragmatic_Sanction_in_1712" title="Pragmatic Sanction in 1712">
        Pragmatic Sanction in 1712
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Subsequently, the emperor pledged to respect all privileges and political rights of
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(Habsburg)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)">
        Kingdom of Croatia
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen_Maria_Theresa" title="Queen Maria Theresa">
        Queen Maria Theresa
       </a>
       made significant contributions to Croatian matters.
      </p>
      <p>
       Between 1797 and 1809 the
       <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">
        First French Empire
       </a>
       gradually occupied the entire eastern
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adriatic" title="Adriatic">
        Adriatic
       </a>
       coastline and a substantial part of its hinterland, ending the Venetian and the Ragusan republics, establishing the
       <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_Provinces" title="Illyrian Provinces">
        Illyrian Provinces
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_33-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-33">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In response the
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">
        Royal Navy
       </a>
       started the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adriatic_campaign_of_1807%E2%80%931814" title="Adriatic campaign of 1807–1814">
        blockade of the Adriatic Sea
       </a>
       leading to the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lissa_(1811)" title="Battle of Lissa (1811)">
        Battle of Vis
       </a>
       in 1811.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdkinsAdkins2008359–362_39-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdkinsAdkins2008359–362-39">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Illyrian Provinces were captured by the Austrians in 1813, and absorbed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">
        Austrian Empire
       </a>
       following the
       <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">
        Congress of Vienna
       </a>
       in 1815. This led to formation of the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Dalmatia" title="Kingdom of Dalmatia">
        Kingdom of Dalmatia
       </a>
       and restoration of the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Littoral" title="Croatian Littoral">
        Croatian Littoral
       </a>
       to the Kingdom of Croatia, now both under the same crown.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The 1830s and 1840s saw
       <a href="/wiki/Romantic_nationalism" title="Romantic nationalism">
        romantic nationalism
       </a>
       inspire the
       <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_movement" title="Illyrian movement">
        Croatian National Revival
       </a>
       , a political and cultural campaign advocating the unity of all
       <a href="/wiki/South_Slavs" title="South Slavs">
        South Slavs
       </a>
       in the empire. Its primary focus was the establishment of a standard language as a counterweight to
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       , along with the promotion of Croatian literature and culture.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRIS-Stančić_41-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CRIS-Stančić-41">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1848">
        Hungarian Revolution of 1848
       </a>
       Croatia sided with the Austrians, Ban
       <a href="/wiki/Josip_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Josip Jelačić">
        Josip Jelačić
       </a>
       helping defeat the Hungarian forces in 1849, and ushering a period of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Germanization" title="Germanization">
        Germanization
       </a>
       policy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       By the 1860s, failure of the policy became apparent, leading to the
       <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Compromise_of_1867" title="Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867">
        Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867
       </a>
       and creation of a
       <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">
        personal union
       </a>
       between the crowns of the Austrian Empire and the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">
        Kingdom of Hungary
       </a>
       . The treaty left the issue of Croatia's status to Hungary, and the status was resolved by the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian%E2%80%93Hungarian_Settlement" title="Croatian–Hungarian Settlement">
        Croatian–Hungarian Settlement
       </a>
       of 1868, when kingdoms of Croatia and Slavonia were united.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Kingdom of Dalmatia remained under de facto Austrian control, while
       <a href="/wiki/Rijeka" title="Rijeka">
        Rijeka
       </a>
       retained the status of
       <a href="/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Fiume)" title="Corpus separatum (Fiume)">
        Corpus separatum
       </a>
       introduced in 1779.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HR-HU-Heka_31-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-HR-HU-Heka-31">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After
       <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
        Austria-Hungary
       </a>
       occupied Bosnia and Herzegovina following the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Berlin_(1878)" title="Treaty of Berlin (1878)">
        1878 Treaty of Berlin
       </a>
       , the Croatian Military Frontier was abolished and the territory returned to Croatia in 1881,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_33-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-33">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       pursuant to provisions of the Croatian-Hungarian settlement.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
        <a href="#cite_note-44">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dubravica_45-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dubravica-45">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Renewed efforts to
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Greater_Austria" title="United States of Greater Austria">
        reform Austria-Hungary
       </a>
       , entailing
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federalisation" title="Federalisation">
        federalisation
       </a>
       with Croatia as a federal unit, were stopped by advent of
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        World War I
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
        <a href="#cite_note-46">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Yugoslavia_.281918.E2.80.931991.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Yugoslavia_(1918–1991)">
        Yugoslavia (1918–1991)
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Creation_of_Yugoslavia" title="Creation of Yugoslavia">
        Creation of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Kingdom of Yugoslavia">
        Kingdom of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Banovina_of_Croatia" title="Banovina of Croatia">
        Banovina of Croatia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_in_Yugoslavia" title="World War II in Yugoslavia">
        World War II in Yugoslavia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">
        Independent State of Croatia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Croatia" title="Socialist Republic of Croatia">
        Socialist Republic of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="312" data-file-width="512" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg/220px-Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg/330px-Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg/440px-Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Stjepan_Radi%C4%87" title="Stjepan Radić">
          Stjepan Radić
         </a>
         , leader of the
         <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Peasant_Party" title="Croatian Peasant Party">
          Croatian Peasant Party
         </a>
         who stood against Serbian hegemony and advocated federal organisation of
         <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Kingdom of Yugoslavia">
          Yugoslavia
         </a>
         , at the assembly in Dubrovnik, 1928
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 29 October 1918 the Croatian Parliament (
       <i>
        Sabor
       </i>
       ) declared independence and decided to join the newly formed
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Slovenes,_Croats_and_Serbs" title="State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs">
        State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Povijest-saborovanja_32-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Povijest-saborovanja-32">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which in turn entered into union with the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">
        Kingdom of Serbia
       </a>
       on 4 December 1918 to form the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats,_and_Slovenes" title="Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes">
        Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
        <a href="#cite_note-47">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Croatian Parliament never ratified a decision to unite with Serbia and Montenegro.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Povijest-saborovanja_32-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Povijest-saborovanja-32">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Vidovdan_Constitution" title="Vidovdan Constitution">
        1921 constitution
       </a>
       defining the country as a
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary state
       </a>
       and abolition of Croatian Parliament and historical administrative divisions effectively ended Croatian autonomy.
      </p>
      <p>
       The new constitution was opposed by the most widely supported national political party—the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Peasant_Party" title="Croatian Peasant Party">
        Croatian Peasant Party
       </a>
       (HSS) led by
       <a href="/wiki/Stjepan_Radi%C4%87" title="Stjepan Radić">
        Stjepan Radić
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The political situation deteriorated further as Radić was assassinated in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Parliament" title="Yugoslav Parliament">
        National Assembly
       </a>
       in 1928, leading to the dictatorship of King
       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Yugoslavia" title="Alexander I of Yugoslavia">
        Alexander
       </a>
       in January 1929.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The dictatorship formally ended in 1931 when the king imposed a more unitarian constitution, and changed the name of the country to Yugoslavia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The HSS, now led by
       <a href="/wiki/Vladko_Ma%C4%8Dek" title="Vladko Maček">
        Vladko Maček
       </a>
       , continued to advocate federalisation of Yugoslavia, resulting in the
       <a href="/wiki/Cvetkovi%C4%87%E2%80%93Ma%C4%8Dek_Agreement" title="Cvetković–Maček Agreement">
        Cvetković–Maček Agreement
       </a>
       of August 1939 and the autonomous
       <a href="/wiki/Banovina_of_Croatia" title="Banovina of Croatia">
        Banovina of Croatia
       </a>
       . The Yugoslav government retained control of defence, internal security, foreign affairs, trade, and transport while other matters were left to the Croatian Sabor and a crown-appointed Ban.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004121–123_51-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004121–123-51">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Adolf_Hitler_meets_Ante_Paveli%C4%87.1941.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="969" data-file-width="1400" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Adolf_Hitler_meets_Ante_Paveli%C4%87.1941.jpg/220px-Adolf_Hitler_meets_Ante_Paveli%C4%87.1941.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Adolf_Hitler_meets_Ante_Paveli%C4%87.1941.jpg/330px-Adolf_Hitler_meets_Ante_Paveli%C4%87.1941.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Adolf_Hitler_meets_Ante_Paveli%C4%87.1941.jpg/440px-Adolf_Hitler_meets_Ante_Paveli%C4%87.1941.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Adolf_Hitler_meets_Ante_Paveli%C4%87.1941.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">
          Adolf Hitler
         </a>
         meets fascist dictator
         <a href="/wiki/Ante_Paveli%C4%87" title="Ante Pavelić">
          Ante Pavelić
         </a>
         upon his arrival at the
         <a href="/wiki/Berghof_(residence)" title="Berghof (residence)">
          Berghof
         </a>
         for a state visit, June 1941
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In April 1941,
       <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Yugoslavia" title="Invasion of Yugoslavia">
        Yugoslavia was occupied
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">
        Germany
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_(1861%E2%80%931946)" title="Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)">
        Italy
       </a>
       . Following the invasion the territory, parts of Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the region of
       <a href="/wiki/Syrmia" title="Syrmia">
        Syrmia
       </a>
       were incorporated into the
       <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">
        Independent State of Croatia
       </a>
       (NDH), a Nazi-backed
       <a href="/wiki/Puppet_state" title="Puppet state">
        puppet state
       </a>
       . Parts of Dalmatia were annexed by Italy and the northern Croatian regions of
       <a href="/wiki/Baranya_(region)" title="Baranya (region)">
        Baranja
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Me%C4%91imurje" title="Međimurje">
        Međimurje
       </a>
       were annexed by Hungary.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004153–156_52-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004153–156-52">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The NDH regime was led by
       <a href="/wiki/Ante_Paveli%C4%87" title="Ante Pavelić">
        Ante Pavelić
       </a>
       and ultranationalist
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Usta%C5%A1e" title="Ustaše">
        Ustaše
       </a>
       . The regime introduced
       <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism" title="Antisemitism">
        anti-semitic
       </a>
       laws and conducted a campaign of
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_persecution_of_Serbs" title="World War II persecution of Serbs">
        ethnic cleansing and genocide against Serb
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">
        Roma
       </a>
       inhabitants of the NDH, exemplified by the
       <a href="/wiki/Jasenovac_concentration_camp" title="Jasenovac concentration camp">
        Jasenovac
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Stara_Gradi%C5%A1ka_concentration_camp" title="Stara Gradiška concentration camp">
        Stara Gradiška
       </a>
       concentration camps.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       It is estimated that out of 39,000
       <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">
        Jews
       </a>
       in the country only 9,000 survived; the rest were either killed or deported to Germany, both by the local authorities and the German Army itself.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatian and Serbian sources disagree on the exact figures.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kočević_55-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kočević-55">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nixontito19712.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1981" data-file-width="2934" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Nixontito19712.jpg/220px-Nixontito19712.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Nixontito19712.jpg/330px-Nixontito19712.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Nixontito19712.jpg/440px-Nixontito19712.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nixontito19712.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">
          Josip Broz Tito
         </a>
         , a Croat by nationality, led
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SFR_Yugoslavia" title="SFR Yugoslavia">
          SFR Yugoslavia
         </a>
         from 1944 to 1980; Pictured: Tito with the US president
         <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">
          Richard Nixon
         </a>
         in the
         <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">
          White House
         </a>
         , 1971
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Furthermore, a significant number of Serbs were killed by the Ustaše on the territory of the NDH during the war. According to Midlarsky, the number of Serbs killed by the regime was at least half a million,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
        <a href="#cite_note-56">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but the figure is contradicted by
       <a href="/wiki/Bogoljub_Ko%C4%8Dovi%C4%87" title="Bogoljub Kočović">
        Bogoljub Kočović
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_%C5%BDerjavi%C4%87" title="Vladimir Žerjavić">
        Vladimir Žerjavić
       </a>
       . Kočović estimated the total number of Serbs killed throughout Yugoslav territory in various circumstances at 487,000, while Žerjavić put the figure at 530,000. Žerjavić indicated that 320,000 Serbs were killed in the NDH, including 82,000 killed among the Yugoslav Partisans, 23,000 killed as Axis collaborators, 25,000 victims of a typhoid epidemic, 45,000 killed by Germans and 15,000 by Italians. Kočović's and Žerjavić's total Yugoslav losses are in agreement with estimates made by Mayers and Campbell of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">
        United States Census Bureau
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The number of Croats killed in the NDH is estimated to be approximately 200,000, either by the Croatian fascist regime, as members of the armed resistance, or as
       <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">
        Axis collaborators
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kočević_55-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kočević-55">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Victims-Cohen_58-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Victims-Cohen-58">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Several thousand of these were killed by the Chetniks; most Croatian historians place the number of Croats killed by the Chetniks on the territory of modern-day Croatia at between 3,000 and 3,500. Croatian estimates for the number of Croats killed by Chetniks in the whole of Yugoslavia range from 18,000 to 32,000 (both combatants and civilians).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A resistance movement soon emerged. On 22 June 1941,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pavličević_60-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pavličević-60">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Sisak_People%27s_Liberation_Partisan_Detachment" title="Sisak People's Liberation Partisan Detachment">
        1st Sisak Partisan Detachment
       </a>
       was formed near
       <a href="/wiki/Sisak" title="Sisak">
        Sisak
       </a>
       , as the first military unit formed by a resistance movement in
       <a href="/wiki/German-occupied_Europe" title="German-occupied Europe">
        occupied Europe
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pavlicevic-2007_61-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pavlicevic-2007-61">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This sparked the beginning of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisan" title="Yugoslav Partisan">
        Yugoslav Partisan
       </a>
       movement, a communist multi-ethnic anti-fascist resistance group led by
       <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">
        Josip Broz Tito
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The movement grew rapidly and at the
       <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Conference" title="Tehran Conference">
        Tehran Conference
       </a>
       in December 1943 the Partisans gained recognition from the
       <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">
        Allies
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       With Allied support in logistics, equipment, training and air power, and with the assistance of
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
        Soviet troops
       </a>
       taking part in the 1944
       <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Offensive" title="Belgrade Offensive">
        Belgrade Offensive
       </a>
       , the Partisans gained control of Yugoslavia and the border regions of
       <a href="/wiki/Trieste#World_War_II_and_its_aftermath" title="Trieste">
        Italy
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carinthia_(state)#From_1920_to_the_Present" title="Carinthia (state)">
        Austria
       </a>
       by May 1945, during which thousands of members of the Ustaše, as well as Croat refugees, were
       <a href="/wiki/Bleiburg_repatriations" title="Bleiburg repatriations">
        killed
       </a>
       by the Yugoslav Partisans.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The political aspirations of the Partisan movement were reflected in the
       <a href="/wiki/State_Anti-fascist_Council_for_the_National_Liberation_of_Croatia" title="State Anti-fascist Council for the National Liberation of Croatia">
        State Anti-fascist Council for the National Liberation of Croatia
       </a>
       , which developed in 1943 as the bearer of Croatian statehood and later transformed into the Parliament of Croatia in 1945, and
