       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AVNOJ" title="AVNOJ">
        AVNOJ
       </a>
       —its counterpart at the Yugoslav level.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="380" data-file-width="600" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG/220px-Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG/330px-Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG/440px-Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A scene from the
         <a href="/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence" title="Croatian War of Independence">
          Croatian War of Independence
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , Croatia became a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Single-party" title="Single-party">
        single-party
       </a>
       socialist
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Croatia" title="Socialist Republic of Croatia">
        federal unit
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">
        SFR Yugoslavia
       </a>
       , ruled by the
       <a href="/wiki/League_of_Communists_of_Croatia" title="League of Communists of Croatia">
        Communists
       </a>
       , but enjoying a degree of autonomy within the federation. In 1967, Croatian authors and linguists published a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Declaration_on_the_Status_and_Name_of_the_Croatian_Standard_Language" title="Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Standard Language">
        Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Standard Language
       </a>
       demanding greater autonomy for
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian language
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Šute-Deklaracija_67-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Šute-Deklaracija-67">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The declaration contributed to a national movement seeking greater civil rights and decentralization of the Yugoslav economy, culminating in the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Spring" title="Croatian Spring">
        Croatian Spring
       </a>
       of 1971, suppressed by Yugoslav leadership.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JL-Savka_68-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-JL-Savka-68">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Still, the
       <a href="/wiki/1974_Yugoslav_Constitution" title="1974 Yugoslav Constitution">
        1974 Yugoslav Constitution
       </a>
       gave increased autonomy to federal units, basically fulfilling a goal of the Croatian Spring, and providing a legal basis for independence of the federative constituents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rich_69-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rich-69">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Following the death of Yugoslav president Josip Broz Tito in 1980, the political situation in Yugoslavia deteriorated, with national tension fanned by the 1986 Serbian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Memorandum_of_the_Serbian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts" title="Memorandum of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts">
        SANU Memorandum
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1989_coups_in_Vojvodina,_Kosovo_and_Montenegro" title="1989 coups in Vojvodina, Kosovo and Montenegro">
        1989 coups in Vojvodina, Kosovo and Montenegro
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005433_70-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005433-70">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In January 1990, the Communist Party fragmented along national lines, with the Croatian
       <a href="/wiki/Political_faction" title="Political faction">
        faction
       </a>
       demanding a looser federation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pauković-14Congress-2009_72-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pauković-14Congress-2009-72">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the same year, the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_parliamentary_election,_1990" title="Croatian parliamentary election, 1990">
        first multi-party elections
       </a>
       were held in Croatia, with
       <a href="/wiki/Franjo_Tu%C4%91man" title="Franjo Tuđman">
        Franjo Tuđman
       </a>
       's win raising nationalist tensions further.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Independent-Tuđman-Obituary_73-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Independent-Tuđman-Obituary-73">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some of
       <a href="/wiki/Serbs_of_Croatia" title="Serbs of Croatia">
        Serbs in Croatia
       </a>
       left Sabor and declared the autonomy of areas that would soon become the unrecognised
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Serbian_Krajina" title="Republic of Serbian Krajina">
        Republic of Serbian Krajina
       </a>
       , intent on achieving independence from Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Autonomy-AUG1990_74-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Autonomy-AUG1990-74">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EE-CIS-book_75-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EE-CIS-book-75">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Independence_.281991.E2.80.93present.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_(1991–present)">
        Independence (1991–present)
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Croatia" title="Independence of Croatia">
        Independence of Croatia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence" title="Croatian War of Independence">
        Croatian War of Independence
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Croatia_since_1995" title="History of Croatia since 1995">
        History of Croatia since 1995
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6084" data-file-width="8268" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg/220px-Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg/330px-Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg/440px-Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Franjo_Tu%C4%91man" title="Franjo Tuđman">
          Franjo Tuđman
         </a>
         was the first democratically elected
         <a href="/wiki/President_of_Croatia" title="President of Croatia">
          President of Croatia
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       As tensions rose, Croatia
       <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Croatia" title="Independence of Croatia">
        declared independence
       </a>
       on 25 June 1991; however, the full implementation of declaration only came into effect on 8 October 1991.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Declaration-26June1991_76-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Declaration-26June1991-76">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sabor-Independence-8Oct1991_77-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sabor-Independence-8Oct1991-77">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the meantime, tensions escalated into
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence" title="Croatian War of Independence">
        overt war
       </a>
       when the
       <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_People%27s_Army" title="Yugoslav People's Army">
        Yugoslav People's Army
       </a>
       (JNA) and various Serb paramilitary groups attacked Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Otkos10_78-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Otkos10-78">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By the end of 1991, a high-intensity conflict fought along a wide front reduced Croatia to control of only about two-thirds of its territory.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Iceland_79-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Iceland-79">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LATimes-OccupiedPct-1Aug91_80-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LATimes-OccupiedPct-1Aug91-80">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The various Serb paramilitary groups then began pursuing a campaign of killing, terror and expulsion against the non-Serb population in the rebel territories, killing thousands of Croat civilians and forcing at least 170,000 from their homes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 15 January 1992, Croatia gained
       <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_recognition" title="Diplomatic recognition">
        diplomatic recognition
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">
        European Economic Community
       </a>
       members, and subsequently the United Nations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Germany-23Dec91_82-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Germany-23Dec91-82">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-UN-membership_83-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYT-UN-membership-83">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The war effectively ended in August 1995 with a
       <a href="/wiki/Operation_Storm" title="Operation Storm">
        decisive victory
       </a>
       by Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LATimes-Storm-Complete_84-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LATimes-Storm-Complete-84">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This was accompanied by the exodus of about 200,000 Serbs from the rebel territories, whose lands were subsequently settled by Croat refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The remaining occupied areas were restored to Croatia pursuant to the
       <a href="/wiki/Erdut_Agreement" title="Erdut Agreement">
        Erdut Agreement
       </a>
       of November 1995, with the process concluded in January 1998.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-UNTAES-16Jan98_86-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-UNTAES-16Jan98-86">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia became a
       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">
        World Trade Organization
       </a>
       (WTO) member on 30 November 2000. The country signed a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stabilization_and_Association_Agreement" title="Stabilization and Association Agreement">
        Stabilization and Association Agreement
       </a>
       (SAA) with the European Union in October 2001. Croatia became a member of NATO on 1 April 2009, and
       <a href="/wiki/2013_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2013 enlargement of the European Union">
        joined
       </a>
       the European Union on 1 July 2013.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Croatia" title="Geography of Croatia">
        Geography of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1894" data-file-width="1912" height="248" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg/250px-Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg/375px-Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg/500px-Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Satellite image of Croatia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zagorje.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Zagorje.jpg/220px-Zagorje.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Zagorje.jpg/330px-Zagorje.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Zagorje.jpg/440px-Zagorje.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Zagorje.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Fields in undulating landscape of the
         <a href="/wiki/Hrvatsko_Zagorje" title="Hrvatsko Zagorje">
          Hrvatsko Zagorje
         </a>
         region
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatia is located in
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
        Central
       </a>
       and Southeast Europe, bordering
       <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">
        Hungary
       </a>
       to the northeast, Serbia to the east,
       <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">
        Bosnia and Herzegovina
       </a>
       to the southeast,
       <a href="/wiki/Montenegro" title="Montenegro">
        Montenegro
       </a>
       to the southeast, the
       <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
        Adriatic Sea
       </a>
       to the southwest and
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">
        Slovenia
       </a>
       to the northwest. It lies mostly between latitudes
       <a href="/wiki/42nd_parallel_north" title="42nd parallel north">
        42°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/47th_parallel_north" title="47th parallel north">
        47° N
       </a>
       and longitudes
       <a href="/wiki/13th_meridian_east" title="13th meridian east">
        13°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/20th_meridian_east" title="20th meridian east">
        20° E
       </a>
       . Part of the territory in the extreme south surrounding
       <a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik" title="Dubrovnik">
        Dubrovnik
       </a>
       is a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Practical_exclave" title="Practical exclave">
        practical exclave
       </a>
       connected to the rest of the mainland by
       <a href="/wiki/Territorial_waters" title="Territorial waters">
        territorial waters
       </a>
       , but separated on land by a short coastline strip belonging to Bosnia and Herzegovina around
       <a href="/wiki/Neum" title="Neum">
        Neum
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Goli.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1488" data-file-width="1984" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Goli.jpg/220px-Goli.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Goli.jpg/330px-Goli.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Goli.jpg/440px-Goli.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Goli.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Croatia has over a
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Croatia" title="List of islands of Croatia">
          thousand islands
         </a>
         ; Pictured: part of
         <a href="/wiki/Mljet" title="Mljet">
          Mljet National Park
         </a>
         , the oldest marine protected area in the Mediterranean
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The territory covers 56,594 square kilometres (21,851 square miles), consisting of 56,414 square kilometres (21,782 square miles) of land and 128 square kilometres (49 square miles) of water. It is the 127th largest country in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_88-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Elevation ranges from the mountains of the
       <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Alps" title="Dinaric Alps">
        Dinaric Alps
       </a>
       with the highest point of the
       <a href="/wiki/Dinara" title="Dinara">
        Dinara
       </a>
       peak at 1,831 metres (6,007 feet) near the border with Bosnia and Herzegovina in the south
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_88-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       to the shore of the Adriatic Sea which makes up its entire southwest border. Insular Croatia consists of over
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Croatia" title="List of islands of Croatia">
        a thousand islands and islets
       </a>
       varying in size, 48 of which are
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_inhabited_islands_of_Croatia" title="List of inhabited islands of Croatia">
        permanently inhabited
       </a>
       . The largest islands are
       <a href="/wiki/Cres" title="Cres">
        Cres
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Krk" title="Krk">
        Krk
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_88-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       each of them having an area of around 405 square kilometres (156 square miles).
      </p>
      <p>
       The hilly northern parts of
       <a href="/wiki/Hrvatsko_Zagorje" title="Hrvatsko Zagorje">
        Hrvatsko Zagorje
       </a>
       and the flat plains of Slavonia in the east which is part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Basin" title="Pannonian Basin">
        Pannonian Basin
       </a>
       are traversed by major rivers such as
       <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">
        Sava
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Drava" title="Drava">
        Drava
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kupa" title="Kupa">
        Kupa
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">
        Danube
       </a>
       . The Danube, Europe's second longest river, runs through the city of
       <a href="/wiki/Vukovar" title="Vukovar">
        Vukovar
       </a>
       in the extreme east and forms part of the border with Serbia. The central and southern regions near the Adriatic coastline and islands consist of low mountains and forested highlands. Natural resources found in the country in quantities significant enough for production include oil, coal, bauxite, low-grade iron ore, calcium, gypsum, natural asphalt, silica, mica, clays, salt and hydropower.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_88-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karst_topography" title="Karst topography">
        Karst topography
       </a>
       makes up about half of Croatia and is especially prominent in the Dinaric Alps.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_caves_in_Croatia" title="List of caves in Croatia">
        a number of deep caves in Croatia
       </a>
       , 49 of which are deeper than 250 m (820.21 ft), 14 of them deeper than 500 m (1,640.42 ft) and three deeper than 1,000 m (3,280.84 ft). Croatia's most famous lakes are the
       <a href="/wiki/Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park" title="Plitvice Lakes National Park">
        Plitvice lakes
       </a>
       , a system of 16 lakes with waterfalls connecting them over
       <a href="/wiki/Dolomite" title="Dolomite">
        dolomite
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">
        limestone
       </a>
       cascades. The lakes are renowned for their distinctive colours, ranging from turquoise to mint green, grey or blue.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC-Plitvice_90-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBC-Plitvice-90">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
        Climate
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Croatia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1026" data-file-width="765" height="295" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Croatia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/220px-Croatia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Croatia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/330px-Croatia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Croatia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/440px-Croatia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Croatia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Köppen climate types of Croatia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="547" data-file-width="800" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg/220px-Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg/330px-Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg/440px-Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Bora_(wind)" title="Bora (wind)">
          Bora
         </a>
         is a dry, cold wind which blows from the mainland out to sea, whose gusts can reach hurricane strength, particularly in the channel below
         <a href="/wiki/Velebit" title="Velebit">
          Velebit
         </a>
         , e.g. in the town of
         <a href="/wiki/Senj" title="Senj">
          Senj
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Most of Croatia has a moderately warm and rainy
       <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">
        continental climate
       </a>
       as defined by the
       <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">
        Köppen climate classification
       </a>
       . Mean monthly temperature ranges between −3
       <a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">
        °C
       </a>
       (27
       <a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">
        °F
       </a>
       ) (in January) and 18 °C (64 °F) (in July). The coldest parts of the country are
       <a href="/wiki/Lika" title="Lika">
        Lika
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Gorski_Kotar" title="Gorski Kotar">
        Gorski Kotar
       </a>
       where snowy forested climate is found at elevations above 1,200 metres (3,900 feet). The warmest areas of Croatia are at the Adriatic coast and especially in its immediate hinterland characterised by the
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">
        Mediterranean climate
       </a>
       , as the temperature highs are moderated by the sea. Consequently, temperature peaks are more pronounced in the continental areas—the lowest temperature of −35.5 °C (−31.9 °F) was recorded on 3 February 1919 in
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%8Cakovec" title="Čakovec">
        Čakovec
       </a>
       , and the highest temperature of 42.4 °C (108.3 °F) was recorded on 5 July 1950 in
       <a href="/wiki/Karlovac" title="Karlovac">
        Karlovac
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201542_91-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201542-91">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Mean annual precipitation ranges between 600 millimetres (24 inches) and 3,500 millimetres (140 inches) depending on geographic region and prevailing climate type. The least precipitation is recorded in the outer islands (
       <a href="/wiki/Vis_(island)" title="Vis (island)">
        Vis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lastovo" title="Lastovo">
        Lastovo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bi%C5%A1evo" title="Biševo">
        Biševo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Svetac" title="Svetac">
        Svetac
       </a>
       ) and in the eastern parts of Slavonia; however, in the latter case, it occurs mostly during the
       <a href="/wiki/Growing_season" title="Growing season">
        growing season
       </a>
       . The maximum precipitation levels are observed on the Dinara mountain range and in Gorski kotar.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201542_91-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201542-91">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Prevailing winds in the interior are light to moderate northeast or southwest, and in the coastal area prevailing winds are determined by local area features. Higher wind velocities are more often recorded in cooler months along the coast, generally as
       <a href="/wiki/Bora_(wind)" title="Bora (wind)">
        bura
       </a>
       or less frequently as
       <a href="/wiki/Sirocco" title="Sirocco">
        sirocco
       </a>
       . The sunniest parts of the country are the outer islands, Hvar and Korčula, where more than 2700 hours of sunshine are recorded per year, followed by the middle and southern Adriatic Sea area in general and northern Adriatic coast, all with more than 2000 hours of sunshine per year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201543_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201543-92">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">
        Biodiversity
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Croatia" title="Protected areas of Croatia">
        Protected areas of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park_(2).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3456" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park_%282%29.jpg/220px-Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park_%282%29.jpg/330px-Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park_%282%29.jpg/440px-Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park_(2).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park" title="Plitvice Lakes National Park">
          Plitvice Lakes National Park
         </a>
         , a UNESCO
         <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
          World Heritage Site
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Telascica-Cliff.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Telascica-Cliff.JPG/220px-Telascica-Cliff.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Telascica-Cliff.JPG/330px-Telascica-Cliff.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Telascica-Cliff.JPG/440px-Telascica-Cliff.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Telascica-Cliff.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Cliffs in
         <a href="/wiki/Tela%C5%A1%C4%87ica" title="Telašćica">
          Telašćica
         </a>
         Nature Park
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paklenica4.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="976" data-file-width="1455" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Paklenica4.jpg/220px-Paklenica4.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Paklenica4.jpg/330px-Paklenica4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Paklenica4.jpg/440px-Paklenica4.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paklenica4.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Paklenica" title="Paklenica">
          Paklenica
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KRKA_juga_-_KRKA_Waterfall.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="848" data-file-width="1600" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/KRKA_juga_-_KRKA_Waterfall.jpg/220px-KRKA_juga_-_KRKA_Waterfall.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/KRKA_juga_-_KRKA_Waterfall.jpg/330px-KRKA_juga_-_KRKA_Waterfall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/KRKA_juga_-_KRKA_Waterfall.jpg/440px-KRKA_juga_-_KRKA_Waterfall.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KRKA_juga_-_KRKA_Waterfall.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Krka_National_Park" title="Krka National Park">
          Krka National Park
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatia can be subdivided between a number of
       <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">
        ecoregions
       </a>
       because of its climate and geomorphology. The country is consequently one of the richest in Europe in terms of biodiversity. There are four types of biogeographical regions in Croatia—Mediterranean along the coast and in its immediate hinterland, Alpine in most of Lika and Gorski Kotar, Pannonian along Drava and Danube, and continental in the remaining areas. One of the most significant are
       <a href="/wiki/Karst" title="Karst">
        karst
       </a>
       habitats which include submerged karst, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Zrmanja" title="Zrmanja">
        Zrmanja
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Krka_(Croatia)" title="Krka (Croatia)">
        Krka
       </a>
       canyons and tufa barriers, as well as underground habitats.
      </p>
      <p>
       The karst geology harbours approximately 7,000 caves and pits, some of which are habitat of the only known aquatic cave
       <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">
        vertebrate
       </a>
       —the
       <a href="/wiki/Olm" title="Olm">
        olm
       </a>
       . Forests are also significantly present in the country, as they cover 2,490,000 hectares (6,200,000 acres) representing 44% of Croatian land surface. Other habitat types include wetlands, grasslands, bogs, fens, scrub habitats, coastal and marine habitats.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_93-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In terms of
       <a href="/wiki/Phytogeography" title="Phytogeography">
        phytogeography
       </a>
       , Croatia is a part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">
        Boreal Kingdom
       </a>
       and is a part of Illyrian and Central European provinces of the
       <a href="/wiki/Circumboreal_Region" title="Circumboreal Region">
        Circumboreal Region
       </a>
       and the Adriatic province of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" title="Mediterranean Region">
        Mediterranean Region
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">
        World Wide Fund for Nature
       </a>
       divides Croatia between three ecoregions—Pannonian mixed forests,
       <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Mountains_mixed_forests" title="Dinaric Mountains mixed forests">
        Dinaric Mountains mixed forests
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_deciduous_forests" title="Illyrian deciduous forests">
        Illyrian deciduous forests
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DU-Sustdev_94-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DU-Sustdev-94">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are 37,000 known species in Croatia, but their actual number is estimated to be between 50,000 and 100,000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_93-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The claim is supported by nearly 400 new taxa of
       <a href="/wiki/Invertebrate" title="Invertebrate">
        invertebrates
       </a>
       discovered in Croatia in the first half of the
       <a href="/wiki/2000s_(decade)" title="2000s (decade)">
        2000s
       </a>
       alone.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_93-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are more than a thousand endemic species, especially in Velebit and Biokovo mountains, Adriatic islands and karst rivers. Legislation protects 1,131 species.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_93-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The most serious threat to species is loss and degradation of habitats. A further problem is presented by invasive alien species, especially
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Caulerpa_taxifolia" title="Caulerpa taxifolia">
         Caulerpa taxifolia
        </a>
       </i>
       algae.
      </p>
      <p>
       The invasive algae are regularly monitored and removed to protect the
       <a href="/wiki/Benthic_zone" title="Benthic zone">
        benthic habitat
       </a>
       . Indigenous sorts of cultivated plants and breeds of domesticated animals are also numerous. Those include five breeds of horses, five breeds of cattle, eight breeds of sheep, two breeds of pigs and a poultry breed. Even the indigenous breeds include nine endangered or critically endangered ones.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_93-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are 444
       <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Croatia" title="Protected areas of Croatia">
        protected areas of Croatia
       </a>
       , encompassing 9% of the country. Those include eight
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Croatia" title="List of national parks of Croatia">
        national parks
       </a>
       , two strict reserves, and ten
       <a href="/wiki/Nature_park" title="Nature park">
        nature parks
       </a>
       . The most famous protected area and the oldest
       <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">
        national park
       </a>
       in Croatia is the Plitvice Lakes National Park, a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_in_Croatia" title="World Heritage Sites in Croatia">
        UNESCO World Heritage Site
       </a>
       . Velebit Nature Park is a part of the UNESCO
       <a href="/wiki/Man_and_the_Biosphere_Programme" title="Man and the Biosphere Programme">
        Man and the Biosphere Programme
       </a>
       . The strict and special reserves, as well as the national and nature parks, are managed and protected by the central government, while other protected areas are managed by counties. In 2005, the National Ecological Network was set up, as the first step in preparation of the EU accession and joining of the
       <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">
        Natura 2000
       </a>
       network.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_93-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
        Politics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Croatia" title="Politics of Croatia">
        Politics of Croatia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Croatia" title="List of political parties in Croatia">
        List of political parties in Croatia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Croatia" title="Human rights in Croatia">
        Human rights in Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:502px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="332" data-file-width="1180" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg/500px-St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg/750px-St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg/1000px-St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg 2x" width="500"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Square,_Zagreb" title="St. Mark's Square, Zagreb">
          St. Mark's Square in Zagreb
         </a>
         –
         <i>
          Left-to-right
         </i>
         :
         <a href="/wiki/Banski_dvori" title="Banski dvori">
          Banski dvori
         </a>
         official residence of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatian_Government" title="Croatian Government">
          Croatian Government
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Church,_Zagreb" title="St. Mark's Church, Zagreb">
          St. Mark's Church
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Parliament" title="Croatian Parliament">
          Croatian Parliament
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Republic of Croatia is a unitary state using a
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
        parliamentary system
       </a>
       of governance. With the collapse of the ruling communist party in SFR Yugoslavia, Croatia organized its first
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">
        multi-party elections
       </a>
       and adopted its
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Croatia" title="Constitution of Croatia">
        present constitution
       </a>
       in 1990.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Elections2-HRV1990_95-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Elections2-HRV1990-95">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It
       <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_independence" title="Declaration of independence">
        declared independence
       </a>
       on 8 October 1991 which led to the
       <a href="/wiki/Breakup_of_Yugoslavia" title="Breakup of Yugoslavia">
        break-up of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       and countries international recognition by the United Nations in 1992.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sabor-Independence-8Oct1991_77-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sabor-Independence-8Oct1991-77">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-UN-membership_83-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYT-UN-membership-83">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under its 1990 constitution, Croatia operated a
       <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">
        semi-presidential system
       </a>
       until 2000 when it switched to a parliamentary system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC-CroProfile_96-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBC-CroProfile-96">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Government powers in Croatia are divided into legislative, executive and judiciary powers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VRH-PoliticalStructure_97-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VRH-PoliticalStructure-97">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Croatia" title="President of Croatia">
        President of the Republic
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="hr">
         Predsjednik Republike
        </span>
       </i>
       ) is the
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
        head of state
       </a>
       , directly elected to a five-year term and is limited by the Constitution to a maximum of two terms. In addition to being the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commander_in_chief" title="Commander in chief">
        commander in chief
       </a>
       of the armed forces, the president has the procedural duty of appointing the prime minister with the consent of the parliament, and has some influence on foreign policy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VRH-PoliticalStructure_97-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-VRH-PoliticalStructure-97">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The most recent presidential elections were held on 11 January 2015, when
       <a href="/wiki/Kolinda_Grabar-Kitarovi%C4%87" title="Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović">
        Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović
       </a>
       won. She took the
       <a href="/wiki/Oath_of_office" title="Oath of office">
        oath of office
       </a>
       on 15 February 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Josipović_98-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Josipović-98">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatian_Government" title="Croatian Government">
        government
       </a>
       is headed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Croatia" title="Prime Minister of Croatia">
        Prime Minister
       </a>
       , who has four deputy prime ministers and 16 ministers in charge of particular sectors of activity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Govt-Ministers_99-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Govt-Ministers-99">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As the
       <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">
        executive branch
       </a>
       , it is responsible for proposing legislation and a budget, executing the laws, and guiding the foreign and internal policies of the republic. The government is seated at
       <a href="/wiki/Banski_dvori" title="Banski dvori">
        Banski dvori
       </a>
       in Zagreb.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VRH-PoliticalStructure_97-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-VRH-PoliticalStructure-97">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since 19 October 2016, Croatian Prime Minister has been
       <a href="/wiki/Andrej_Plenkovi%C4%87" title="Andrej Plenković">
        Andrej Plenković
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The parliament (
       <i>
        <span lang="hr">
         Sabor
        </span>
       </i>
       ) is a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">
        unicameral
       </a>
       legislative body. A second
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chambers_of_parliament" title="Chambers of parliament">
        chamber
       </a>
       , the
       <i>
        House of Counties
       </i>
       , set up in 1993 pursuant to the 1990 Constitution, was abolished in 2001. The number of Sabor members can vary from 100 to 160; they are all elected by popular vote to serve four-year terms. The sessions of the Sabor take place from 15 January to 15 July, and from 15 September to 15 December.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sabor-about_100-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sabor-about-100">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The two largest political parties in Croatia are the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Democratic_Union" title="Croatian Democratic Union">
        Croatian Democratic Union
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Croatia" title="Social Democratic Party of Croatia">
        Social Democratic Party of Croatia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sabor-MPs_101-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sabor-MPs-101">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_judicial_system">
        Law and judicial system
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Croatia" title="Law of Croatia">
        Law of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg/200px-Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg/300px-Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg/400px-Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Seat of the
         <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Croatia" title="Constitutional Court of Croatia">
          Constitutional Court
         </a>
         on the
         <a href="/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Square,_Zagreb" title="St. Mark's Square, Zagreb">
          St. Mark's Square, Zagreb
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatia has a
       <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">
        civil law
       </a>
       legal system in which law arises primarily from written statutes, with judges serving merely as implementers, and not creators of law. Its development was largely influenced by German and Austrian legal systems. Croatian law is divided into two principal areas –
       <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(Civil_law)" title="Civil law (Civil law)">
        private
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Public_law" title="Public law">
        public law
       </a>
       . By the time
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Accession_of_Croatia_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Croatia to the European Union">
        EU accession negotiations
       </a>
       were completed on 30 June 2010, Croatian legislation was fully harmonised with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Community_acquis" title="Community acquis">
        Community acquis
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DELHRV-overview_102-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DELHRV-overview-102">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The main law in the county is the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Croatia" title="Constitution of Croatia">
        Constitution
       </a>
       adopted on December 22, 1990.
      </p>
      <p>
       The main national courts are the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Croatia" title="Constitutional Court of Croatia">
        Constitutional Court
       </a>
       , which oversees violations of the Constitution, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Croatia" title="Supreme Court of Croatia">
        Supreme Court
       </a>
       , which is the highest court of appeal. In addition, there are also
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/County_Court" title="County Court">
        County
       </a>
       , Municipal, Misdemeanor, Commercial, and Administrative courts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VSRH-about_103-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VSRH-about-103">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cases falling within judicial jurisdiction are in the first instance decided by a single professional judge, while appeals are deliberated in mixed tribunals of professional judges. Lay magistrates also participate in trials.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/State%27s_Attorney_Office_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia" title="State's Attorney Office of the Republic of Croatia">
        State's Attorney Office
       </a>
       is the judicial body constituted of public prosecutors that is empowered to instigate prosecution of perpetrators of offences.
      </p>
      <p>
       Law enforcement agencies are organised under the authority of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Croatia)" title="Ministry of the Interior (Croatia)">
        Ministry of the Interior
       </a>
       which consist primarily of the national police force. Croatia's security service is the
       <a href="/wiki/Security_and_Intelligence_Agency" title="Security and Intelligence Agency">
        Security and Intelligence Agency
       </a>
       (SOA).
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">
        Administrative divisions
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Croatia" title="Counties of Croatia">
        Counties of Croatia
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NUTS_of_Croatia" title="NUTS of Croatia">
        NUTS of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vara%C5%BEdinska_%C5%BEupanija,_sjedi%C5%A1te.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2134" data-file-width="2848" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Vara%C5%BEdinska_%C5%BEupanija%2C_sjedi%C5%A1te.jpg/200px-Vara%C5%BEdinska_%C5%BEupanija%2C_sjedi%C5%A1te.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Vara%C5%BEdinska_%C5%BEupanija%2C_sjedi%C5%A1te.jpg/300px-Vara%C5%BEdinska_%C5%BEupanija%2C_sjedi%C5%A1te.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Vara%C5%BEdinska_%C5%BEupanija%2C_sjedi%C5%A1te.jpg/400px-Vara%C5%BEdinska_%C5%BEupanija%2C_sjedi%C5%A1te.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vara%C5%BEdinska_%C5%BEupanija,_sjedi%C5%A1te.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Vara%C5%BEdin_County" title="Varaždin County">
          Varaždin County
         </a>
         seat
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatia was first subdivided into counties in the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Medieval-Counties_105-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Medieval-Counties-105">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The divisions changed over time to reflect losses of territory to Ottoman conquest and subsequent liberation of the same territory, changes of political status of Dalmatia, Dubrovnik and
       <a href="/wiki/Istria" title="Istria">
        Istria
       </a>
       . Traditional division of the country into counties was abolished in the 1920s, when the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes and subsequent Kingdom of Yugoslavia introduced
       <a href="/wiki/Oblast" title="Oblast">
        oblasts
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_the_Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Subdivisions of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia">
        banovinas
       </a>
       respectively.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005429_106-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005429-106">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Communist-ruled Croatia, as a constituent part of post-World War II Yugoslavia, abolished earlier divisions and introduced municipalities, subdividing Croatia into approximately one hundred municipalities. Counties were reintroduced in 1992 legislation, significantly altered in terms of territory relative to the pre-1920s subdivisions: In 1918, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transleithania" title="Transleithania">
        Transleithanian
       </a>
       part of Croatia was divided into eight counties with their seats in
       <a href="/wiki/Bjelovar" title="Bjelovar">
        Bjelovar
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Gospi%C4%87" title="Gospić">
        Gospić
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ogulin" title="Ogulin">
        Ogulin
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Osijek" title="Osijek">
        Osijek
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Po%C5%BEega,_Croatia" title="Požega, Croatia">
        Požega
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vara%C5%BEdin" title="Varaždin">
        Varaždin
       </a>
       , Vukovar, and Zagreb, and the 1992 legislation established 14 counties in the same territory.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiondich200011_107-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiondich200011-107">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CountiesAct1992_108-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CountiesAct1992-108">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the counties were re-established in 1992, Croatia is divided into 20
       <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Croatia" title="Counties of Croatia">
        counties
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Zagreb" title="Zagreb">
        capital city of Zagreb
       </a>
       , the latter having the authority and legal status of a county and a city at the same time. Borders of the counties changed in some instances since, with the latest revision taking place in 2006. The counties subdivide into 127
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Croatia" title="List of cities in Croatia">
        cities
       </a>
       and 429
       <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Croatia" title="Municipalities of Croatia">
        municipalities
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CountiesAct2006_109-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CountiesAct2006-109">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Nomenclature_of_Territorial_Units_for_Statistics" title="Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics">
        Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics
       </a>
       (NUTS)
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NUTS_of_Croatia" title="NUTS of Croatia">
        division of Croatia
       </a>
       is performed in several tiers. NUTS 1 level places the entire country in a single unit, while there are three NUTS 2 regions. Those are Northwest Croatia, Central and Eastern (Pannonian) Croatia and Adriatic Croatia. The latter encompasses all the counties along the Adriatic coast. The Northwest Croatia includes the city of Zagreb, Zagreb, Krapina-Zagorje, Varaždin, Koprivnica-Križevci and Međimurje counties, and the Central and Eastern (Pannonian) Croatia includes the remaining areas—Bjelovar-Bilogora, Virovitica-Podravina, Požega-Slavonia, Brod-Posavina, Osijek-Baranja, Vukovar-Syrmia, Karlovac and Sisak-Moslavina counties. Individual counties and the city of Zagreb also represent NUTS 3 level subdivision units in Croatia. The NUTS
       <a href="/wiki/Local_administrative_unit" title="Local administrative unit">
        Local administrative unit
       </a>
       divisions are two-tiered. LAU 1 divisions match the counties and the city of Zagreb in effect making those the same as NUTS 3 units, while LAU 2 subdivisions correspond to the cities and municipalities of Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
        <a href="#cite_note-110">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="position: relative; ;">
       <div class="noviewer thumb tleft">
        <div class="thumbinner" style="width:502px">
         <div style="position:relative;width:500px;border:1px solid lightgray">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Counties_of_Croatia.svg" title="Map of Croatian counties and county capitals. Zagreb is capital of the Zagreb County enveloping the city of Zagreb">
           <img alt="Map of Croatian counties and county capitals. Zagreb is capital of the Zagreb County enveloping the city of Zagreb" data-file-height="1062" data-file-width="1097" height="484" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Counties_of_Croatia.svg/500px-Counties_of_Croatia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Counties_of_Croatia.svg/750px-Counties_of_Croatia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Counties_of_Croatia.svg/1000px-Counties_of_Croatia.svg.png 2x" width="500"/>
          </a>
          <div style="position:absolute;top:31.206%;left:67.402%">
           <div style="position:absolute;left:-3px;top:-3px;line-height:0">
            <img alt="Požega" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="6" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/6px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/9px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Požega" width="6"/>
           </div>
           <div style="font-size:75%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;bottom:4px;left:-3em;text-align:center">
            <span style="padding:1px">
             <b>
              <a href="/wiki/Po%C5%BEega,_Croatia" title="Požega, Croatia">
               Požega
              </a>
             </b>
            </span>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div style="position:absolute;top:20.567%;left:62.99%">
           <div style="position:absolute;left:-3px;top:-3px;line-height:0">
            <img alt="Virovitica" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="6" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/6px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/9px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Virovitica" width="6"/>
           </div>
           <div style="font-size:75%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:4px;left:-3em;text-align:center">
            <span style="padding:1px">
             <b>
              <a href="/wiki/Virovitica" title="Virovitica">
               Virovitica
              </a>
             </b>
            </span>
           </div>
          </div>
