      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="428" data-file-width="1191" height="79" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg/220px-Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg/330px-Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg/440px-Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Flag hoisting ceremony at
         <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Croatia)" title="Ministry of Defence (Croatia)">
          Ministry of Defence
         </a>
         marking Croatian accession to the
         <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
          NATO
         </a>
         in 2009
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="310" data-file-width="521" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/220px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/330px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/440px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Croatia became a member of the
         <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
          European Union
         </a>
         on 1 July 2013
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatia has established diplomatic relations with 181 countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tportal-DiplRel_111-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tportal-DiplRel-111">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It's considered a
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">
        middle power
       </a>
       in international affairs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Croatian_Foreign_Policy:_From_State_Building_to_the_Regional_Power_112-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Croatian_Foreign_Policy:_From_State_Building_to_the_Regional_Power-112">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Central_Europe_Top_500:_An_era_of_digital_transformation_113-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Central_Europe_Top_500:_An_era_of_digital_transformation-113">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Croatia:_an_Overview_of_its_History,_Culture_and_Science_114-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Croatia:_an_Overview_of_its_History,_Culture_and_Science-114">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Was_Nikola_Tesla_a_Serbian?_or,_the_Origin_of_Nikola_Tesla_115-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Was_Nikola_Tesla_a_Serbian?_or,_the_Origin_of_Nikola_Tesla-115">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Croatia:_A_History_116-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Croatia:_A_History-116">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2009
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , Croatia maintains a network of 51 embassies, 24 consulates and eight permanent diplomatic missions abroad. Furthermore, there are 52 foreign embassies and 69
       <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)" title="Consul (representative)">
        consulates
       </a>
       in the Republic of Croatia in addition to offices of international organisations such as the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Bank_for_Reconstruction_and_Development" title="European Bank for Reconstruction and Development">
        European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/International_Organization_for_Migration" title="International Organization for Migration">
        International Organization for Migration
       </a>
       , OSCE,
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">
        World Health Organization
       </a>
       (WHO),
       <a href="/wiki/International_Criminal_Tribunal_for_the_former_Yugoslavia" title="International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia">
        International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
       </a>
       (ICTY),
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme" title="United Nations Development Programme">
        United Nations Development Programme
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees">
        United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/UNICEF" title="UNICEF">
        UNICEF
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MVP-foreign-missions_117-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MVP-foreign-missions-117">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2009, the Croatian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_and_European_Integration_(Croatia)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration (Croatia)">
        Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration
       </a>
       employed 1,381 personnel and expended 648.2 million kuna (€86.4 million).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MVPEI-Audit-2009_118-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MVPEI-Audit-2009-118">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Stated aims of Croatian foreign policy include enhancing relations with neighbouring countries, developing international co-operation and promotion of the Croatian economy and Croatia itself.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MVPEI-Goals_119-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MVPEI-Goals-119">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since 2003, Croatian foreign policy has focused on achieving the strategic goal of becoming a
       <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">
        member state of the European Union
       </a>
       (EU).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU-NATO-StrategicGoals-NCL_120-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EU-NATO-StrategicGoals-NCL-120">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sabor-EU-NATO-Strategic_121-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sabor-EU-NATO-Strategic-121">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In December 2011, Croatia completed the EU accession negotiations and signed
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Accession_2011" title="Treaty of Accession 2011">
        an EU accession treaty
       </a>
       on 9 December 2011.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU-Negotiations-Completed_122-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EU-Negotiations-Completed-122">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU-Accession-Treaty_123-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EU-Accession-Treaty-123">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia joined the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       on 1 July 2013 marking the end of a process started in 2001 by signing of the
       <a href="/wiki/Stabilisation_and_Association_Process" title="Stabilisation and Association Process">
        Stabilisation and Association Agreement
       </a>
       and Croatian application for the EU membership in 2003.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Croatia-EU-2013_124-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Croatia-EU-2013-124">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A recurring obstacle to the negotiations was Croatia's ICTY co-operation record and Slovenian blocking of the negotiations because of
       <a href="/wiki/Croatia%E2%80%93Slovenia_border_disputes" title="Croatia–Slovenia border disputes">
        Croatia–Slovenia border disputes
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The latter was resolved through an Arbitration Agreement of 4 November 2009, approved by national parliaments and a referendum in Slovenia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Croatia-Slovenia-Arbitration_127-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Croatia-Slovenia-Arbitration-127">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Another strategic Croatian foreign policy goal for the 2000s was
       <a href="/wiki/Croatia%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="Croatia–NATO relations">
        NATO membership
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU-NATO-StrategicGoals-NCL_120-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-EU-NATO-StrategicGoals-NCL-120">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sabor-EU-NATO-Strategic_121-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sabor-EU-NATO-Strategic-121">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia was included in the
       <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">
        Partnership for Peace
       </a>
       in 2000, invited to
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       membership in 2008 and formally joined the alliance on 1 April 2009.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Bush-Zagreb_128-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Bush-Zagreb-128">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC-Croatia-NATO_129-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBC-Croatia-NATO-129">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia became a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">
        United Nations Security Council
       </a>
       for the 2008–2009 term, assuming presidency in December 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MVPEI-UNSC-2008-2009_130-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MVPEI-UNSC-2008-2009-130">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country is preparing to join the
       <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">
        Schengen Area
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
        Military
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Croatia_Armed_Forces" title="Republic of Croatia Armed Forces">
        Republic of Croatia Armed Forces
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1369" data-file-width="2100" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg/220px-US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg/330px-US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg/440px-US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatian_Air_Force" title="Croatian Air Force">
          Croatian Air Force
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_Navy" title="US Navy">
          US Navy
         </a>
         aircraft participate in multinational training, 2002
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Croatian Armed Forces (CAF) consist of the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Army" title="Croatian Army">
        Army
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Navy" title="Croatian Navy">
        Navy
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Air_Force_and_Air_Defence" title="Croatian Air Force and Air Defence">
        Air Force
       </a>
       branches in addition to the Education and Training Command and Support Command. The CAF is headed by the
       <a href="/wiki/General_Staff_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia" title="General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Croatia">
        General Staff
       </a>
       , which reports to the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Croatia)" title="Ministry of Defence (Croatia)">
        Defence Minister
       </a>
       , who in turn reports to the President of Croatia. According to the constitution, the President is
       <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">
        commander-in-chief
       </a>
       of the armed forces and in case of immediate threat during wartime he issues orders directly to the General Staff.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CAFstructure_132-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CAFstructure-132">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Degman_041.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="679" data-file-width="1280" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Degman_041.jpg/220px-Degman_041.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Degman_041.jpg/330px-Degman_041.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Degman_041.jpg/440px-Degman_041.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Degman_041.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/M-95_Degman" title="M-95 Degman">
          M-95 Degman
         </a>
         , a prototype Croatian main battle tank
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Following the 1991–95 war defence spending and CAF size have been in constant decline. As of 2005
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       military spending was an estimated 2.39% of the country's GDP, which placed Croatia 64th in a ranking of all countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_88-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since 2005 the budget was kept below 2% of GDP, down from the record high of 11.1% in 1994.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sipri_133-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-sipri-133">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Traditionally relying on a large number of conscripts, CAF also went through a period of reforms focused on downsizing, restructuring and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Professionalisation" title="Professionalisation">
        professionalisation
       </a>
       in the years prior to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Accession_of_Croatia_to_NATO" title="Accession of Croatia to NATO">
        Croatia's accession to NATO
       </a>
       in April 2009. According to a presidential decree issued in 2006 the CAF is set to employ 18,100 active duty military personnel, 3,000 civilians and 2,000 voluntary conscripts between the ages of 18 and 30 in peacetime.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CAFstructure_132-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-CAFstructure-132">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Compulsory conscription was abolished in January 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_88-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Until 2008 military service was compulsory for men at age 18 and conscripts served six-month tours of duty, reduced in 2001 from the earlier scheme of nine-month conscription tours. Conscientious objectors could instead opt for an eight-month civilian service.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vojnirokkraci_134-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-vojnirokkraci-134">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of April 2011
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the Croatian military had 120 members stationed in foreign countries as part of United Nations-led international peacekeeping forces, including 95 serving as part of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Disengagement_Observer_Force_Zone" title="United Nations Disengagement Observer Force Zone">
        UNDOF
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">
        Golan Heights
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNmirovne_135-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNmirovne-135">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2011
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       an additional 350 troops serve as part of the NATO-led
       <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">
        ISAF
       </a>
       force in Afghanistan and another 20 with the
       <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">
        KFOR
       </a>
       in Kosovo.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ezadar_136-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ezadar-136">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kosorkosovo_137-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-kosorkosovo-137">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Croatia also has a significant
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_industry" title="Military industry">
        military industry
       </a>
       sector which exported around US$120 million worth of military equipment and armament in 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vojna_ind_138-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-vojna_ind-138">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatian-made weapons and vehicles used by CAF include the standard sidearm
       <a href="/wiki/HS2000" title="HS2000">
        HS2000
       </a>
       manufactured by
       <a href="/wiki/HS_Produkt" title="HS Produkt">
        HS Produkt
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/M-84D" title="M-84D">
        M-84D
       </a>
       battle tank designed by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90uro_%C4%90akovi%C4%87_(factory)" title="Đuro Đaković (factory)">
        Đuro Đaković factory
       </a>
       . Uniforms and helmets worn by CAF soldiers are also locally produced and successfully marketed to other countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vojna_ind_138-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-vojna_ind-138">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Croatia" title="Economy of Croatia">
        Economy of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istria3.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Istria3.JPG/220px-Istria3.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Istria3.JPG/330px-Istria3.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Istria3.JPG/440px-Istria3.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istria3.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Istria" title="Istria">
          Istrian
         </a>
         vineyards;
         <a href="/wiki/Croatian_wine" title="Croatian wine">
          Wine
         </a>
         is produced in nearly all regions of Croatia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div style="float:right; margin-right:10px">
       <table class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right;">
        <tr style="background:#efefef;">
         <th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;">
          The largest Croatian companies by turnover in 2015
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Deloitte-HRV-2015_139-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-Deloitte-HRV-2015-139">
            [138]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Deloitte500-2010-HR_140-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-Deloitte500-2010-HR-140">
            [139]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;">
          Rank
         </th>
         <th style="text-align:center;">
          Name
         </th>
         <th style="text-align:center;">
          Revenue
          <br/>
          (Mil. €)
         </th>
         <th style="text-align:center;">
          Profit
          <br/>
          (Mil. €)
          <br/>
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          1
         </td>

          </a>
         </td>

         </td>

         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>

           INA
          </a>
         </td>
         <td>
          <img alt="Decrease" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" title="Decrease" width="11"/>

         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>

         </td>
         <td style="text-align:left;">
          <a href="/wiki/Konzum" title="Konzum">
           Konzum
          </a>
         </td>
         <td>
          <img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/>

         </td>

          18
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          4
         </td>
         <td style="text-align:left;">
          <a href="/wiki/Hrvatska_elektroprivreda" title="Hrvatska elektroprivreda">
           Hrvatska elektroprivreda
          </a>
          (HEP)
         </td>
         <td>
          <img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/>
          1,694
         </td>
         <td>
          <img alt="Decrease" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" title="Decrease" width="11"/>
          260
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          5
         </td>
         <td style="text-align:left;">
          <a href="/wiki/List_of_companies_of_Croatia" title="List of companies of Croatia">
           Orbico Group
          </a>
         </td>
         <td>
          <img alt="Steady" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Steady2.svg/11px-Steady2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Steady2.svg/17px-Steady2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Steady2.svg/22px-Steady2.svg.png 2x" title="Steady" width="11"/>
          1,253
         </td>
         <td>
          <img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/>
          17
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatia is classified as a high-income economy by the United Nations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
        <a href="#cite_note-141">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">
        International Monetary Fund
       </a>
       data projects that Croatian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" title="Nominal GDP">
        nominal GDP
       </a>
       stands at $53.5 billion, or $12,863 per capita for year 2017, while
       <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">
        purchasing power parity
       </a>
       GDP stands at $100 billion, or $24,095 per capita.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WEO2017_142-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WEO2017-142">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">
        Eurostat
       </a>
       data, Croatian PPS GDP per capita stood at 61% of the EU average in 2012.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eurostat-GDPPC_143-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Eurostat-GDPPC-143">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Real GDP growth in 2007 was 6.0 per cent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eurostat-GDPGrowth_144-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Eurostat-GDPGrowth-144">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The average net salary of a Croatian worker in January 2017 was 5,895
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_kuna" title="Croatian kuna">
        HRK
       </a>
       per month, and the average gross salary was 7,911 HRK per month.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-salary7161_145-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-salary7161-145">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of February 2017, registered unemployment rate in Croatia was 15.3%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2010, economic output was dominated by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Service_sector" title="Service sector">
        service sector
       </a>
       which accounted for 66% of GDP, followed by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrial_sector" title="Industrial sector">
        industrial sector
       </a>
       with 27.2% and agriculture accounting for 6.8% of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to 2004 data, 2.7% of the workforce were employed in agriculture, 32.8% by industry and 64.5% in services.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_88-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
        <a href="#cite_note-148">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The industrial sector is dominated by shipbuilding, food processing, pharmaceuticals, information technology, biochemical and timber industry. In 2010, Croatian exports were valued at 64.9 billion kuna (€8.65 billion) with 110.3 billion kuna (€14.7 billion) worth of imports. The largest
       <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">
        trading partner
       </a>
       is rest of the European Union.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       More than half of Croatia's trade is with other European Union member states.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">
        Privatization
       </a>
       and the drive toward a
       <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">
        market economy
       </a>
       had barely begun under the new Croatian Government when war broke out in 1991. As a result of the war, the economic infrastructure sustained massive damage, particularly the revenue-rich tourism industry. From 1989 to 1993, the GDP fell 40.5%. The Croatian state still controls a significant part of the economy, with government expenditures accounting for as much as 40% of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DOS_151-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DOS-151">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A backlogged judiciary system, combined with inefficient
       <a href="/wiki/Public_administration" title="Public administration">
        public administration
       </a>
       , especially on issues of land ownership and corruption, are particular concerns. In the 2015
       <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">
        Corruption Perceptions Index
       </a>
       , published by
       <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">
        Transparency International
       </a>
       , the country is ranked joint 50th with a score of 51, where zero denotes "highly corrupt" and 100 "very clean".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPI_152-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CPI-152">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In June 2013, the national debt stood at 59.5% of the nation's GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">
        Tourism
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Croatia" title="Tourism in Croatia">
        Tourism in Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bol_na_Bracu_-_Zlatni_rat.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Bol_na_Bracu_-_Zlatni_rat.jpg/220px-Bol_na_Bracu_-_Zlatni_rat.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Bol_na_Bracu_-_Zlatni_rat.jpg/330px-Bol_na_Bracu_-_Zlatni_rat.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Bol_na_Bracu_-_Zlatni_rat.jpg/440px-Bol_na_Bracu_-_Zlatni_rat.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bol_na_Bracu_-_Zlatni_rat.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Zlatni_Rat" title="Zlatni Rat">
          Zlatni Rat
         </a>
         beach on the Island of
         <a href="/wiki/Bra%C4%8D" title="Brač">
          Brač
         </a>
         is one of foremost spots of
         <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Croatia" title="Tourism in Croatia">
          tourism in Croatia
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism" title="Tourism">
        Tourism
       </a>
       dominates the Croatian service sector and accounts for up to 20% of Croatian GDP. Annual tourist industry income for 2014 was estimated at €7.4 billion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
        <a href="#cite_note-154">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Its positive effects are felt throughout the economy of Croatia in terms of increased business volume observed in retail business, processing industry orders and summer seasonal employment. The industry is considered an export business, because it significantly reduces the country's external trade imbalance.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since the conclusion of the Croatian War of Independence, the tourist industry has grown rapidly, recording a fourfold rise in tourist numbers, with more than 11 million tourists each year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia412_156-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia412-156">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The most numerous are tourists from Germany, Slovenia, Austria, Italy and the
       <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">
        Czech Republic
       </a>
       as well as Croatia itself.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia415_157-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia415-157">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Length of a tourist stay in Croatia averages 4.9 days.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The bulk of the tourist industry is concentrated along the Adriatic Sea coast.
       <a href="/wiki/Opatija" title="Opatija">
        Opatija
       </a>
       was the first holiday resort since the middle of the 19th century. By the 1890s, it became one of the most significant European health resorts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Later a number of resorts sprang up along the coast and islands, offering services ranging from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mass_tourism" title="Mass tourism">
        mass tourism
       </a>
       to catering and various niche markets, the most significant being
       <a href="/wiki/Nautical_tourism" title="Nautical tourism">
        nautical tourism
       </a>
       , as there are numerous marinas with more than 16 thousand berths,
       <a href="/wiki/Cultural_tourism" title="Cultural tourism">
        cultural tourism
       </a>
       relying on appeal of medieval coastal cities and numerous cultural events taking place during the summer. Inland areas offer mountain resorts,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agrotourism" title="Agrotourism">
        agrotourism
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Spa" title="Spa">
        spas
       </a>
       . Zagreb is also a significant tourist destination, rivalling major coastal cities and resorts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Croatia has unpolluted marine areas reflected through numerous nature reserves and 116
       <a href="/wiki/Blue_Flag_beach" title="Blue Flag beach">
        Blue Flag beaches
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
        <a href="#cite_note-161">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia is ranked as the 18th most popular tourist destination in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNWTO_162-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNWTO-162">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       About 15% of these visitors (over one million per year) are involved with
       <a href="/wiki/Naturism" title="Naturism">
        naturism
       </a>
       , an industry for which Croatia is world-famous. It was also the first European country to develop commercial naturist resorts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">
        Infrastructure
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Croatia" title="Transport in Croatia">
        Transport in Croatia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Croatia" title="Energy in Croatia">
        Energy in Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Novi_putni%C4%8Dki_terminal_.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2958" data-file-width="5258" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Novi_putni%C4%8Dki_terminal_.jpg/220px-Novi_putni%C4%8Dki_terminal_.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Novi_putni%C4%8Dki_terminal_.jpg/330px-Novi_putni%C4%8Dki_terminal_.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Novi_putni%C4%8Dki_terminal_.jpg/440px-Novi_putni%C4%8Dki_terminal_.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Novi_putni%C4%8Dki_terminal_.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Zagreb_Airport" title="Zagreb Airport">
          Zagreb Airport
         </a>
         is the largest and busiest international airport in the country
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A1_near_junction_Maslenica.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="4608" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/A1_near_junction_Maslenica.jpg/220px-A1_near_junction_Maslenica.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/A1_near_junction_Maslenica.jpg/330px-A1_near_junction_Maslenica.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/A1_near_junction_Maslenica.jpg/440px-A1_near_junction_Maslenica.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A1_near_junction_Maslenica.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Croatia has over 1250 km of
         <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Croatia" title="Highways in Croatia">
          modern highways
         </a>
         most of which were built in the early 2000s; Pictured:
         <a href="/wiki/A1_(Croatia)" title="A1 (Croatia)">
          A1
         </a>
         motorway near
         <a href="/wiki/Maslenica" title="Maslenica">
          Maslenica
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The highlight of Croatia's recent infrastructure developments is its rapidly developed
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Motorways_in_Croatia" title="Motorways in Croatia">
        motorway network
       </a>
       , largely built in the late 1990s and especially in the 2000s (decade). By September 2011, Croatia had completed more than 1,100 kilometres (680 miles) of motorways, connecting Zagreb to most other regions and following various
       <a href="/wiki/International_E-road_network" title="International E-road network">
        European routes
       </a>
       and four
       <a href="/wiki/Pan-European_corridors" title="Pan-European corridors">
        Pan-European corridors
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Helsinki-1997_164-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Helsinki-1997-164">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NN-Motorways2007_165-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NN-Motorways2007-165">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NN-Motorways2009_166-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NN-Motorways2009-166">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The busiest motorways are the
       <a href="/wiki/A1_(Croatia)" title="A1 (Croatia)">
        A1
       </a>
       , connecting Zagreb to Split and the
       <a href="/wiki/A3_(Croatia)" title="A3 (Croatia)">
        A3
       </a>
       , passing east–west through northwest Croatia and Slavonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HC-promet_167-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HC-promet-167">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A widespread network of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_roads_in_Croatia" title="State roads in Croatia">
        state roads in Croatia
       </a>
       acts as motorway
       <a href="/wiki/Feeder_line_(network)" title="Feeder line (network)">
        feeder roads
       </a>
       while connecting all major settlements in the country. The high quality and safety levels of the Croatian motorway network were tested and confirmed by several EuroTAP and EuroTest programs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:H%C5%BE_6112.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="1080" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/H%C5%BE_6112.jpg/220px-H%C5%BE_6112.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/H%C5%BE_6112.jpg/330px-H%C5%BE_6112.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/H%C5%BE_6112.jpg/440px-H%C5%BE_6112.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:H%C5%BE_6112.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Railways" title="Croatian Railways">
          Croatian Railways
         </a>
         train HŽ 6112
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Luka_brajdica_040408.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="408" data-file-width="640" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Luka_brajdica_040408.jpg/220px-Luka_brajdica_040408.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Luka_brajdica_040408.jpg/330px-Luka_brajdica_040408.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Luka_brajdica_040408.jpg/440px-Luka_brajdica_040408.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Luka_brajdica_040408.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Rijeka" title="Port of Rijeka">
          Port of Rijeka
         </a>
         is the largest Croatian seaport
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatia has an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_railways_in_Croatia" title="List of railways in Croatia">
        extensive rail network
       </a>
       spanning 2,722 kilometres (1,691 miles), including 984 kilometres (611 miles) of electrified railways and 254 kilometres (158 miles) of double track railways.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia346_170-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia346-170">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The most significant railways in Croatia are found within the Pan-European transport corridors Vb and X connecting Rijeka to Budapest and Ljubljana to Belgrade, both via Zagreb.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Helsinki-1997_164-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Helsinki-1997-164">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       All rail services are operated by
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Railways" title="Croatian Railways">
        Croatian Railways
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are
       <a href="/wiki/International_airport" title="International airport">
        international airports
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik_Airport" title="Dubrovnik Airport">
        Dubrovnik
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Osijek_Airport" title="Osijek Airport">
        Osijek
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pula_Airport" title="Pula Airport">
        Pula
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rijeka_Airport" title="Rijeka Airport">
        Rijeka
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Split_Airport" title="Split Airport">
        Split
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Zadar_Airport" title="Zadar Airport">
        Zadar
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zagreb_International_Airport" title="Zagreb International Airport">
        Zagreb
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MMPI-Airports_172-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MMPI-Airports-172">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The largest and busiest is Franjo Tuđman Airport.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of January 2011, Croatia complies with
       <a href="/wiki/International_Civil_Aviation_Organization" title="International Civil Aviation Organization">
        International Civil Aviation Organization
       </a>
       aviation safety standards and the
       <a href="/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration" title="Federal Aviation Administration">
        Federal Aviation Administration
       </a>
       upgraded it to Category 1 rating.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The busiest cargo
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seaport" title="Seaport">
        seaport
       </a>
       in Croatia is the
       <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Rijeka" title="Port of Rijeka">
        Port of Rijeka
       </a>
       and the busiest passenger ports are
       <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Split" title="Port of Split">
        Split
       </a>
       and Zadar.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WB-Rijeka_175-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WB-Rijeka-175">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MMPI-RL-plan_176-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MMPI-RL-plan-176">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition to those, a large number of minor ports serve an extensive system of ferries connecting numerous islands and coastal cities in addition to ferry lines to several cities in Italy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AOLPP-Rijeka_177-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AOLPP-Rijeka-177">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The largest river port is Vukovar, located on the Danube, representing the nation's outlet to the Pan-European transport corridor VII.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Helsinki-1997_164-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Helsinki-1997-164">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MMPI-River-Navigation_178-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MMPI-River-Navigation-178">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are 610 kilometres (380 miles) of crude oil pipelines in Croatia, connecting the Port of Rijeka oil terminal with refineries in Rijeka and Sisak, as well as several transhipment terminals. The system has a capacity of 20 million tonnes per year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JANAF-system_179-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-JANAF-system-179">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The natural gas transportation system comprises 2,113 kilometres (1,313 miles) of trunk and regional natural gas pipelines, and more than 300 associated structures, connecting production rigs, the Okoli natural gas storage facility, 27 end-users and 37 distribution systems.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Plinacro-system_180-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Plinacro-system-180">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Croatian production of energy sources covers 85% of nationwide natural gas demand and 19% of oil demand. In 2008, 47.6% of Croatia's primary energy production structure comprised use of natural gas (47.7%), crude oil (18.0%), fuel wood (8.4%), hydro power (25.4%) and other renewable energy sources (0.5%). In 2009, net total electrical power production in Croatia reached 12,725 GWh and Croatia imported 28.5% of its electric power energy needs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The bulk of Croatian imports are supplied by the
       <a href="/wiki/Kr%C5%A1ko_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Krško Nuclear Power Plant">
        Krško Nuclear Power Plant
       </a>
       , 50% owned by
       <a href="/wiki/Hrvatska_elektroprivreda" title="Hrvatska elektroprivreda">
        Hrvatska elektroprivreda
       </a>
       , providing 15% of Croatia's electricity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUB-NEK_181-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EUB-NEK-181">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Croatia" title="Demographics of Croatia">
        Demographics of Croatia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Croats" title="Croats">
        Croats
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Census_2011.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2361" data-file-width="2409" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Census_2011.png/220px-Census_2011.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Census_2011.png/330px-Census_2011.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Census_2011.png/440px-Census_2011.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Census_2011.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         2011 census ethnic structure by municipalities, Red: Croats, Blue: Serbs, Yellow: Italians, Green: Hungarians, Purple: Czechs
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 0.5em;">
       <tr>
        <th class="navbox-title" colspan="3" style="padding:0.25em;font-size:110%">
         Historical population
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr style="font-size:95%">
        <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;width:3em">

         </abbr>

         </abbr>
        </th>
       </tr>

         —
        </td>
       </tr>

        </td>

         3,785,455
        </td>

         +9.9%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">

        </th>

        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         −0.1%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1953
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         3,936,022
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +4.1%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1961
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         4,159,696
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +5.7%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1971
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         4,426,221
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +6.4%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         1981
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         4,601,469
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
         +4.0%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         1991
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         4,784,265
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         +4.0%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         2002
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         4,492,049
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         −6.1%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
         2011
        </th>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         4,456,096
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
         −0.8%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">
         As of 29 June 2011
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       With its estimated population of 4,19 million in 2016, Croatia
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">
        ranks 125th by population
       </a>
       in the world. Its
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density">
        population density
       </a>
       stands at 75.9 inhabitants per square kilometre. The overall
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">
        life expectancy in Croatia
       </a>
       at birth was 78 years in 2012.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-who0_182-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-who0-182">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">
        total fertility rate
       </a>
       of 1.5 children per mother, is one of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_fertility_rate" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by fertility rate">
        lowest in the world
       </a>
       . Since 1991, Croatia's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Death_rate" title="Death rate">
        death rate
       </a>
       has continuously exceeded its
       <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">
        birth rate
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since the late 1990s, there has been a positive net migration into Croatia, reaching a level of more than 7,000 net immigrants in 2006.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Limun-immigration_183-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Limun-immigration-183">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the 2013 United Nations report, 17.6% of Croatia's population were foreign-born immigrants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Bureau_of_Statistics" title="Croatian Bureau of Statistics">
        Croatian Bureau of Statistics
       </a>
       forecast that the population may shrink to 3.1 million by 2051, depending on actual birth rate and the level of net migration.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Forecast-2051_185-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Forecast-2051-185">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The population of Croatia rose steadily from 2.1 million in 1857 until 1991, when it peaked at 4.7 million, with exception of censuses taken in 1921 and 1948, i.e. following two world wars.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The natural growth rate of the population is currently negative
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_88-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with the
       <a href="/wiki/Demographic_transition" title="Demographic transition">
        demographic transition
       </a>
       completed in the 1970s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In recent years, the Croatian government has been pressured each year to add 40% to work permit quotas for foreign workers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
        <a href="#cite_note-187">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In accordance with its immigration policy, Croatia is trying to entice emigrants to return.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The population decrease was also a result of the Croatian War of Independence. During the war, large sections of the population were displaced and emigration increased. In 1991, in predominantly Serb areas, more than 400,000 Croats and other non-Serbs were either removed from their homes by the Croatian Serb forces or fled the violence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
        <a href="#cite_note-189">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the final days of the war in 1995, more than 120,000 Serbs,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and perhaps as many as 200,000,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       fled the country before arrival of Croatian forces during Operation Storm. Within a decade following the end of the war, only 117,000 Serb refugees returned out of 300,000 displaced during the entire war.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OSCE-Reform_192-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-OSCE-Reform-192">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Most of Croatia's remaining Serbs never lived in areas occupied in the Croatian War of Independence. Serbs have been only partially re-settled in the regions they previously inhabited while some of the settlements previously inhabited by Serbs were settled by Croat refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina, mostly from
       <a href="/wiki/Republika_Srpska" title="Republika Srpska">
        Republika Srpska
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Index-Cro-Refugees_193-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Index-Cro-Refugees-193">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PresidentRH-refugees_194-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PresidentRH-refugees-194">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Croatia is inhabited mostly by Croats (90.4%) and is ethnically the most
       <a href="/wiki/Homogeneity_and_heterogeneity" title="Homogeneity and heterogeneity">
        homogeneous
       </a>
       of the six countries of former Yugoslavia. Minority groups include Serbs (4.4%),
       <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks" title="Bosniaks">
        Bosniaks
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarians" title="Hungarians">
        Hungarians
       </a>
       , Italians,
       <a href="/wiki/Slovenes" title="Slovenes">
        Slovenes
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">
        Germans
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Czechs" title="Czechs">
        Czechs
       </a>
       , Romani people and others (5.9%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2011-nationality_2-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Census2011-nationality-2">
         [1]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marija_Bistrica_-_crkva.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1224" data-file-width="1632" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Marija_Bistrica_-_crkva.JPG/220px-Marija_Bistrica_-_crkva.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Marija_Bistrica_-_crkva.JPG/330px-Marija_Bistrica_-_crkva.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Marija_Bistrica_-_crkva.JPG/440px-Marija_Bistrica_-_crkva.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marija_Bistrica_-_crkva.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Shrine of Saint Mary of
         <a href="/wiki/Marija_Bistrica" title="Marija Bistrica">
          Marija Bistrica
         </a>
         , a popular religious destination.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Croatia" title="Religion in Croatia">
        Religion in Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
         <tr style="background:#ddd">

             [194]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </th>
         </tr>

          </td>

          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">
           percent
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
            Roman Catholicism
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:yellow; width:86.28%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           86.28%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">
            Eastern Orthodoxy
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:darkred; width:4.44%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           4.44%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
            Islam
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:Green; width:1.47%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           1.47%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">
            Protestantism
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:blue; width:0.34%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.34%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">
            Atheism
           </a>
           or Agnosticism
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:black; width:4.57%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           4.57%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Others and unspecified
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:grey; width:3.24%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           3.24%
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatia has no official religion.
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">
        Freedom of religion
       </a>
       is a right defined by the Constitution which also defines all
       <a href="/wiki/Religious_denomination" title="Religious denomination">
        religious communities
       </a>
       as
       <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state" title="Separation of church and state">
        equal in front of the law and separated from the state
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the 2011 census, 91.36% of Croatians identify as Christian; of these, Roman Catholics make up the largest group, accounting for 86.28% of the population, after which follows
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy" title="Eastern Orthodoxy">
        Eastern Orthodoxy
       </a>
       (4.44%),
       <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">
        Protestantism
       </a>
       (0.34%) and other Christianity (0.30%). Second largest religion is
       <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
        Islam
       </a>
       (1.47%). 4.57% of the population describes themselves as non-religious.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2011-religion_196-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Census2011-religion-196">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">
        Eurostat
       </a>
       Eurobarometer Poll of 2005, 67% of the population of Croatia responded that "they believe there is a God".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In a 2009 Gallup poll, 70% answered yes to the question "Is religion an important part of your daily life?".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
        <a href="#cite_note-198">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, only 24% of the population attends religious services regularly.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew_Survey_2017_-_Final_Topline_199-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pew_Survey_2017_-_Final_Topline-199">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="infobox" style="text-align:center; width:97%; margin-right:10px; font-size:90%">
