      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
        Languages
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Languages_of_Croatia" title="Languages of Croatia">
        Languages of Croatia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Serbo-Croatian" title="Serbo-Croatian">
        Serbo-Croatian
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian language
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="620" height="290" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png/300px-Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png/450px-Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png/600px-Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Map of the dialects of Croatia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table class="mbox-small" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div class="center">
          <div class="floatnone">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" width="50"/>
          </div>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em">
         <div class="haudio">
          <div style="padding:4px 0">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.wav" title="File:Baška tablet.wav">
            Speech example
           </a>
          </div>
          <div>
           <div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px">
            <audio class="kskin" controls="" data-durationhint="66.012789115646" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Baška_tablet.wav" data-startoffset="0" id="mwe_player_1" preload="none" style="width:220px">
             <source data-bandwidth="84568" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg Vorbis" data-title="Ogg Vorbis" data-transcodekey="ogg" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/2/2a/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.wav/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.wav.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/>
             <source data-bandwidth="135048" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/2/2a/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.wav/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.wav.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/>
             <source data-bandwidth="1411200" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="WAV source" data-title="Original WAV file (1.41 Mbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2a/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet.wav" type="audio/wav"/>
            </audio>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">
           An example of Old Croatian used in the
           <a href="/wiki/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet" title="Baška tablet">
            Baška tablet
           </a>
           .
          </div>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-text" colspan="2" style="line-height:1.1em">
         <hr/>
         <span>
          <i>
           Problems playing this file? See
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">
            media help
           </a>
           .
          </i>
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       is the official language of Croatia, and became the 24th official language of the European Union upon its accession in 2013.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ustav-RH_201-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ustav-RH-201">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VL-Hrvatski-EU_202-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VL-Hrvatski-EU-202">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Minority languages are in official use in local government units where more than a third of population consists of national minorities or where local legislation defines so. Those languages are
       <a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">
        Czech
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language_in_Croatia" title="Italian language in Croatia">
        Italian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ruthenian_language" title="Ruthenian language">
        Ruthenian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Serbian_language_in_Croatia" title="Serbian language in Croatia">
        Serbian
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovakian_language" title="Slovakian language">
        Slovakian
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the 2011 Census, 95.6% of citizens of Croatia declared Croatian as their native language, 1.2% declared Serbian as their native language, while no other language is represented in Croatia by more than 0.5% of native speakers among population of Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census-2011-languages_204-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Census-2011-languages-204">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatian is one of the five spoken languages of the
       <a href="/wiki/South_Slavic_languages" title="South Slavic languages">
        Western South Slavic group
       </a>
       and one of the eighteen spoken
       <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">
        Slavic languages
       </a>
       . Croatian is written using the Latin alphabet. It has three major
       <a href="/wiki/Dialect" title="Dialect">
        dialects
       </a>
       represented, with standard Croatian based on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shtokavian_dialect" title="Shtokavian dialect">
        Shtokavian dialect
       </a>
       . The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chakavian_dialect" title="Chakavian dialect">
        Chakavian
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kajkavian_dialect" title="Kajkavian dialect">
        Kajkavian
       </a>
       dialects are distinguished by their
       <a href="/wiki/Lexicon" title="Lexicon">
        lexicon
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Phonology" title="Phonology">
        phonology
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Syntax" title="Syntax">
        syntax
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brozović-HRV_205-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Brozović-HRV-205">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From 1961 to 1991, the official language was
       <a href="/wiki/Serbo-Croatian" title="Serbo-Croatian">
        Serbo-Croatian
       </a>
       . Even during
       <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">
        socialist rule
       </a>
       , Croats always referred to their language as Croatian, instead of Serbo-Croatian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatian and Serbian variants of the language were not officially recognised as different at the time, but referred to as the west and east version, and had different alphabets: the
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">
        Latin alphabet
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Cyrillic_alphabet" title="Serbian Cyrillic alphabet">
        Serbian Cyrillic
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brozović-HRV_205-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Brozović-HRV-205">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatians are protective of their Croatian language from foreign influences, as the language was under constant change and threats imposed by previous rulers (i.e. Austrian German, Hungarian, Italian and Turkish words were changed and altered to Slavic looking or sounding ones). Efforts made to impose policies to alter Croatian into "Serbo-Croatian" or "South Slavic" language, met resistance from Croats in form of
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_linguistic_purism" title="Croatian linguistic purism">
        Croatian linguistic purism
       </a>
       . Croatian replaced
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">
        Latin
       </a>
       as the official language of the Croatian government in the 19th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Iadertina-Hr_207-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Iadertina-Hr-207">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A 2011 survey revealed that 78% of Croatians claim knowledge of at least one foreign language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Index-lang_208-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Index-lang-208">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to a survey ordered by the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">
        European Commission
       </a>
       in 2005, 49% of Croatians speak
       <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
        English
       </a>
       as the second language, 34% speak
       <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">
        German
       </a>
       , 14% speak
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       and 10% speak
       <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
        French
       </a>
       . Russian is spoken by 4% each, and 2% of Croatians speak Spanish. However, there are large municipalities
       <a href="/wiki/Minority_languages_of_Croatia" title="Minority languages of Croatia">
        that have minority languages
       </a>
       that include substantial populations that speak these languages. An odd-majority of Slovenes (59%) have a certain level of knowledge of Croatian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EBS-243_209-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EBS-243-209">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country is a part of various language-based international associations most notably the
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union" title="Languages of the European Union">
        European Union Language Association.
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Croatia" title="Education in Croatia">
        Education in Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:University_of_Zagreb.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="2304" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/University_of_Zagreb.jpg/200px-University_of_Zagreb.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/University_of_Zagreb.jpg/300px-University_of_Zagreb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/University_of_Zagreb.jpg/400px-University_of_Zagreb.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:University_of_Zagreb.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zagreb" title="University of Zagreb">
          University of Zagreb
         </a>
         is the largest Croatian university and the oldest university in the area covering
         <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
          Central Europe
         </a>
         south of
         <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">
          Vienna
         </a>
         and all of
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" title="Southeastern Europe">
          Southeastern Europe
         </a>
         (1669)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Split_University_Library-wide.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="551" data-file-width="1024" height="108" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Split_University_Library-wide.jpg/200px-Split_University_Library-wide.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Split_University_Library-wide.jpg/300px-Split_University_Library-wide.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Split_University_Library-wide.jpg/400px-Split_University_Library-wide.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Split_University_Library-wide.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Library of the
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Split" title="University of Split">
          University of Split
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Literacy in Croatia stands at 99.2 per cent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A worldwide study about the quality of living in different countries published by
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Newsweek" title="Newsweek">
         Newsweek
        </a>
       </i>
       in August 2010 ranked the Croatian education system at 22nd, to share the position with Austria.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newsweek-ranking_212-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Newsweek-ranking-212">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Primary education in Croatia starts at the age of six or seven and consists of eight grades. In 2007 a law was passed to increase free, noncompulsory education until 18 years of age. Compulsory education consists of eight grades of elementary school. Secondary education is provided by
       <a href="/wiki/Gymnasium_(school)" title="Gymnasium (school)">
        gymnasiums
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vocational_school" title="Vocational school">
        vocational schools
       </a>
       . As of 2014
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , there are 2,055 elementary schools and 707 schools providing various forms of secondary education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_213-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-213">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Primary and secondary education are also available in languages of recognized minorities in Croatia, where classes are held in Czech, German, Hungarian, Italian, and Serbian languages.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia488_214-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia488-214">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are 132 elementary and secondary level
       <a href="/wiki/Music_school" title="Music school">
        music
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Art_schools" title="Art schools">
        art schools
       </a>
       , as well as 120 schools for disabled children and youth and 74 schools for adults.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_213-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-213">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nationwide
       <a href="/wiki/Matura" title="Matura">
        leaving exams
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="hr">
         državna matura
        </span>
       </i>
       ) were introduced for secondary education students in the school year 2009–2010. It comprises three compulsory subjects (Croatian language, mathematics, and a foreign language) and optional subjects and is a prerequisite for university education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MZOS-Matura_215-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MZOS-Matura-215">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Croatia has 8 public universities, the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Dubrovnik" title="University of Dubrovnik">
        University of Dubrovnik
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Osijek" title="University of Osijek">
        University of Osijek
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Pula" title="University of Pula">
        University of Pula
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Rijeka" title="University of Rijeka">
        University of Rijeka
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Split" title="University of Split">
        University of Split
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zadar" title="University of Zadar">
        University of Zadar
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zagreb" title="University of Zagreb">
        University of Zagreb
       </a>
       , and 2 private universities,
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_University_of_Croatia" title="Catholic University of Croatia">
        Catholic University of Croatia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik_International_University" title="Dubrovnik International University">
        Dubrovnik International University
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_216-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-216">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The University of Zadar, the first university in Croatia, was founded in 1396 and remained active until 1807, when other institutions of higher education took over until the foundation of the renewed University of Zadar in 2002.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zadar-Uni_217-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Zadar-Uni-217">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The University of Zagreb, founded in 1669, is the oldest continuously operating university in Southeast Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zagreb-Uni_218-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Zagreb-Uni-218">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are also 15
       <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_technology" title="Institute of technology">
        polytechnics
       </a>
       , of which 2 are private, and 30 higher education institutions, of which 27 are private.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_216-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-216">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In total, there are 55 institutions of higher education in Croatia, attended by more than 157 thousand students.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_213-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-213">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are 205 companies, government or education system institutions and non-profit organisations in Croatia pursuing scientific research and development of technology. Combined, they spent more than 3 billion kuna (€400 million) and employed 10,191 full-time research staff in 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Among the scientific institutes operating in Croatia, the largest is the
       <a href="/wiki/Ru%C4%91er_Bo%C5%A1kovi%C4%87_Institute" title="Ruđer Bošković Institute">
        Ruđer Bošković Institute
       </a>
       in Zagreb.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JL-IRB_219-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-JL-IRB-219">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts" title="Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts">
        Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts
       </a>
       in Zagreb is a
       <a href="/wiki/Learned_society" title="Learned society">
        learned society
       </a>
       promoting language, culture, arts and science from its inception in 1866.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HAZU-founding_220-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HAZU-founding-220">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia has also
       <a href="/wiki/Category:Croatian_inventors" title="Category:Croatian inventors">
        produced inventors
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country#Croatia" title="List of Nobel laureates by country">
        two Croatians
       </a>
       received the Nobel Prize.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">
        Health
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_in_Croatia" title="Health in Croatia">
        Health in Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="530" data-file-width="751" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg/200px-KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg/300px-KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg/400px-KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/University_Hospital_Centre_Zagreb" title="University Hospital Centre Zagreb">
          University Hospital Centre Zagreb
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatia has a
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">
        universal health care
       </a>
       system, whose roots can be traced back to the Hungarian-Croatian Parliament Act of 1891, providing a form of mandatory insurance of all factory workers and craftsmen.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RSP-1891_221-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-RSP-1891-221">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The population is covered by a basic health insurance plan provided by statute and optional insurance. In 2012, annual healthcare related expenditures reached 21.0 billion kuna (€2.8 billion).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia548_222-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia548-222">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Healthcare expenditures comprise only 0.6% of private health insurance and public spending.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vjesnik-Zdravstvo_223-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Vjesnik-Zdravstvo-223">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2010, Croatia spent 6.9% of its GDP on healthcare.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WB-Health_224-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WB-Health-224">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia ranked around the 40th in the world in life expectancy with 74 years for men and 81 years for women, and it had a low
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Infant_mortality_rate" title="Infant mortality rate">
        infant mortality rate
       </a>
       of 5 per 1,000
       <a href="/wiki/Live_birth_(human)" title="Live birth (human)">
        live births
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-who0_182-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-who0-182">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHO-Croatia-Stat_225-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WHO-Croatia-Stat-225">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are hundreds of healthcare institutions in Croatia, including 79 hospitals and clinics with 23,967 beds. The hospitals and clinics care for more than 700 thousand patients per year and employ 5,205
       <a href="/wiki/Doctor_of_Medicine" title="Doctor of Medicine">
        medical doctors
       </a>
       , including 3,929 specialists. There are 6,379 private practice offices, and a total of 41,271 health workers in the country. There are 63 emergency medical service units, responding to more than a million calls. The principal cause of death in 2008 was
       <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">
        cardiovascular disease
       </a>
       at 43.5% for men and 57.2% for women, followed by tumours, at 29.4% for men and 21.4% for women. In 2009 only 13 Croatians had been infected with HIV/AIDS and 6 had died from the disease.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2008 it was estimated by the WHO that 27.4% of Croatians over age of 15 are smokers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Poslovni-smoking_226-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Poslovni-smoking-226">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to 2003 WHO data, 22% of the Croatian adult population is obese.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHO-Core_227-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WHO-Core-227">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Croatia" title="Culture of Croatia">
        Culture of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Casco_viejo_de_Dubrovnik,_Croacia,_2014-04-14,_DD_07.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3574" data-file-width="5556" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Casco_viejo_de_Dubrovnik%2C_Croacia%2C_2014-04-14%2C_DD_07.JPG/200px-Casco_viejo_de_Dubrovnik%2C_Croacia%2C_2014-04-14%2C_DD_07.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Casco_viejo_de_Dubrovnik%2C_Croacia%2C_2014-04-14%2C_DD_07.JPG/300px-Casco_viejo_de_Dubrovnik%2C_Croacia%2C_2014-04-14%2C_DD_07.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Casco_viejo_de_Dubrovnik%2C_Croacia%2C_2014-04-14%2C_DD_07.JPG/400px-Casco_viejo_de_Dubrovnik%2C_Croacia%2C_2014-04-14%2C_DD_07.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Casco_viejo_de_Dubrovnik,_Croacia,_2014-04-14,_DD_07.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Old Town of
         <a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik" title="Dubrovnik">
          Dubrovnik
         </a>
         has been included in the
         <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
          UNESCO
         </a>
         list of
         <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
          World Heritage Sites
         </a>
         since 1979.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Because of its geographic position, Croatia represents a blend of four different cultural spheres. It has been a crossroad of influences of the western culture and the east—ever since division of the
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">
        Western Roman Empire
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Byzantine Empire
       </a>
       —as well as of the
       <a href="/wiki/Mitteleuropa" title="Mitteleuropa">
        Mitteleuropa
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_culture" title="Mediterranean culture">
        Mediterranean culture
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HTZ-History-Culture_228-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HTZ-History-Culture-228">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Illyrian movement was the most significant period of national cultural history, as the 19th-century period proved crucial in emancipation of the Croatian language and saw unprecedented developments in all fields of art and culture, giving rise to a number of
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Croatia#People" title="Culture of Croatia">
        historical figures
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRIS-Stančić_41-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-CRIS-Stančić-41">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(Croatia)" title="Ministry of Culture (Croatia)">
        Ministry of Culture
       </a>
       of the Republic of Croatia is tasked with preserving the nation's
       <a href="/wiki/Natural_and_Cultural_Heritage_of_Croatia" title="Natural and Cultural Heritage of Croatia">
        cultural and natural heritage
       </a>
       and overseeing its development. Further activities supporting development of culture are undertaken at local government level.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MKult-Djelokrug_229-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MKult-Djelokrug-229">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
        UNESCO
       </a>
       's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Table_of_World_Heritage_Sites_by_country" title="Table of World Heritage Sites by country">
        World Heritage List
       </a>
       includes seven sites in Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNESCO-WH_230-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNESCO-WH-230">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country is also rich with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intangible_culture" title="Intangible culture">
        Intangible culture
       </a>
       and holds ten of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Representative_List_of_the_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_of_Humanity" title="Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity">
        UNESCO's World's intangible culture masterpieces
       </a>
       , surpassing all countries in Europe except Spain which possesses an equal number of the listed items.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNESCO-Masterpieces_231-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNESCO-Masterpieces-231">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A global cultural contribution from Croatia is the necktie, derived from the
       <a href="/wiki/Cravat" title="Cravat">
        cravat
       </a>
       originally worn by the 17th-century Croatian mercenaries in France.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-tie_232-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYT-tie-232">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Huzjan_233-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Huzjan-233">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Necktie-colour-isolation.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1228" data-file-width="1818" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Necktie-colour-isolation.jpg/200px-Necktie-colour-isolation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Necktie-colour-isolation.jpg/300px-Necktie-colour-isolation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Necktie-colour-isolation.jpg/400px-Necktie-colour-isolation.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Necktie-colour-isolation.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Necktie" title="Necktie">
          necktie
         </a>
         originates from
         <a href="/wiki/Cravat" title="Cravat">
          cravat
         </a>
         worn by 17th-century Croat soldiers.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-tie_232-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-NYT-tie-232">
           [231]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Huzjan_233-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-Huzjan-233">
           [232]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG/200px-Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG/300px-Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG/400px-Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_Castle" title="Trakošćan Castle">
          Trakošćan Castle
         </a>
         is one of the best preserved historic buildings in the country.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
          <a href="#cite_note-234">
           [233]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       As of 2015
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , Croatia has 98 professional theatres, 29 professional children's theatres and 57 amateur theatres visited by more than 1.9 million viewers per year. The professional theatres employ 1,183 artists. There are 50 professional orchestras, ensembles, and choirs in the country, attracting an annual attendance of 270 thousand. There are 164 cinemas with attendance exceeding 4.3 million.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2015_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia510–512_235-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2015_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia510–512-235">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia has 222 museums, visited by more than 2.7 million people in 2015. Furthermore, there are 1,781 libraries in the country, containing 26.1 million volumes, and 19 state archives.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2015_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia540-543_236-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2015_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia540-543-236">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2009, more than 7,200 books and brochures were published, along with 2,678 magazines and 314 newspapers. There are also 146 radio stations and 21 TV stations operating in the country. In past five years, film production in Croatia produced up to five feature films and 10 to 51 short films, with an additional 76 to 112 TV films. As of 2009
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , there are 784 amateur cultural and artistic associations and more than 10 thousand cultural, educational and artistic events held annually.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The book publishing market is dominated by several major publishers and the industry's centrepiece event—
       <a href="/wiki/Interliber" title="Interliber">
        Interliber
       </a>
       exhibition held annually at
       <a href="/wiki/Zagreb_Fair" title="Zagreb Fair">
        Zagreb Fair
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JL-Interliber_237-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-JL-Interliber-237">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Croatia is categorised as having established a very high level of human development in the
       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
        Human Development Index
       </a>
       , with a high degree of equality in HDI achievements between women and men.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_7-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-HDI-7">
         [6]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It promotes
       <a href="/wiki/Disability_rights_movement" title="Disability rights movement">
        disability rights
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU-Disability_238-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EU-Disability-238">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Recognition_of_same-sex_unions_in_Croatia" title="Recognition of same-sex unions in Croatia">
        Recognition of same-sex unions in Croatia
       </a>
       has gradually improved over the past decade, culminating in registered
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_unions" title="Civil unions">
        civil unions
       </a>
       in July 2014, granting same-sex couples equal inheritance rights, tax deductions and limited adoption rights.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
        <a href="#cite_note-239">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition, in December 2013 Croatians voted in a
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_constitutional_referendum,_2013" title="Croatian constitutional referendum, 2013">
        constitutional referendum
       </a>
       and approved changes to constitution to define marriage as a union between a man and a woman.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gay_marriage_reuters_240-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gay_marriage_reuters-240">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Arts_and_literature">
        Arts and literature
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_art" title="Croatian art">
        Croatian art
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Croatia" title="Architecture of Croatia">
        Architecture of Croatia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_literature" title="Croatian literature">
        Croatian literature
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HR-Sibenik-Kathedrale-01.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3272" data-file-width="3349" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/HR-Sibenik-Kathedrale-01.jpg/220px-HR-Sibenik-Kathedrale-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/HR-Sibenik-Kathedrale-01.jpg/330px-HR-Sibenik-Kathedrale-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/HR-Sibenik-Kathedrale-01.jpg/440px-HR-Sibenik-Kathedrale-01.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HR-Sibenik-Kathedrale-01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ibenik_Cathedral" title="Šibenik Cathedral">
          Šibenik Cathedral
         </a>
         has been included in the
         <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
          UNESCO
         </a>
         list of
         <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
          World Heritage Sites
         </a>
         in year 2000.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:De_Gondola.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1512" data-file-width="1124" height="296" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/De_Gondola.jpg/220px-De_Gondola.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/De_Gondola.jpg/330px-De_Gondola.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/De_Gondola.jpg/440px-De_Gondola.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:De_Gondola.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Gunduli%C4%87" title="Ivan Gundulić">
          Ivan Gundulić
         </a>
         , the most prominent Croatian
         <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">
          Baroque
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Poetry" title="Poetry">
          poet
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Architecture in Croatia reflects influences of bordering nations. Austrian and Hungarian influence is visible in public spaces and buildings in the north and in the central regions, architecture found along coasts of Dalmatia and Istria exhibits Venetian influence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Large squares named after culture heroes, well-groomed parks, and pedestrian-only zones, are features of these orderly towns and cities, especially where large scale
       <a href="/wiki/Baroque_architecture" title="Baroque architecture">
        Baroque
       </a>
       urban planning took place, for instance in Osijek (
       <a href="/wiki/Tvr%C4%91a" title="Tvrđa">
        Tvrđa
       </a>
       ), Varaždin and Karlovac.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Telegraph-Baroque_242-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Telegraph-Baroque-242">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JL-Karlovac-Baroque_243-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-JL-Karlovac-Baroque-243">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Subsequent influence of the
       <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">
        Art Nouveau
       </a>
       was reflected in contemporary architecture.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IPU-Art-Nouveau_244-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-IPU-Art-Nouveau-244">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Along the coast, the architecture is Mediterranean with a strong Venetian and Renaissance influence in major urban areas exemplified in works of
       <a href="/wiki/Giorgio_da_Sebenico" title="Giorgio da Sebenico">
        Giorgio da Sebenico
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Fiorentino" title="Niccolò Fiorentino">
        Niccolò Fiorentino
       </a>
       such as the
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ibenik_Cathedral" title="Šibenik Cathedral">
        Cathedral of St. James
       </a>
       in Šibenik. The oldest preserved examples of Croatian architecture are the 9th-century churches, with the largest and the most representative among them being
       <a href="/wiki/Church_of_St._Donatus" title="Church of St. Donatus">
        Church of St. Donatus
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Zadar" title="Zadar">
        Zadar
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MVPEI-Art_245-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MVPEI-Art-245">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TZZadar-Donat_246-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TZZadar-Donat-246">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Besides the architecture encompassing the oldest artworks in Croatia, there is a long history of artists in Croatia reaching to the Middle Ages. In that period the stone portal of the
       <a href="/wiki/Trogir_Cathedral" title="Trogir Cathedral">
        Trogir Cathedral
       </a>
       was made by
       <a href="/wiki/Radovan_(master)" title="Radovan (master)">
        Radovan
       </a>
       , representing the most important monument of
       <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_art" title="Romanesque art">
        Romanesque
       </a>
       sculpture from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatia_in_the_union_with_Hungary" title="Croatia in the union with Hungary">
        Medieval Croatia
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Croatia" title="Renaissance in Croatia">
        Renaissance
       </a>
       had the greatest impact on the Adriatic Sea coast since the remainder of Croatia was embroiled in the Hundred Years' Croatian–Ottoman War. With the waning of the Ottoman Empire, art flourished during the
       <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">
        Baroque
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">
        Rococo
       </a>
       . The 19th and the 20th centuries brought about affirmation of numerous Croatian artisans, helped by several patrons of the arts such as bishop
       <a href="/wiki/Josip_Juraj_Strossmayer" title="Josip Juraj Strossmayer">
        Josip Juraj Strossmayer
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Essehist-Strossmayer_247-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Essehist-Strossmayer-247">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatian artists of the period achieving worldwide renown were
       <a href="/wiki/Vlaho_Bukovac" title="Vlaho Bukovac">
        Vlaho Bukovac
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Me%C5%A1trovi%C4%87" title="Ivan Meštrović">
        Ivan Meštrović
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MVPEI-Art_245-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-MVPEI-Art-245">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Baška tablet, a stone inscribed with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Glagolitic_alphabet" title="Glagolitic alphabet">
        glagolitic alphabet
       </a>
       found on the Krk island and dated to 1100, is considered to be the oldest surviving prose in Croatian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KRK-Baška_248-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-KRK-Baška-248">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The beginning of more vigorous development of Croatian literature is marked by the Renaissance and
       <a href="/wiki/Marko_Maruli%C4%87" title="Marko Marulić">
        Marko Marulić
       </a>
       . Besides Marulić, Renaissance playwright
       <a href="/wiki/Marin_Dr%C5%BEi%C4%87" title="Marin Držić">
        Marin Držić
       </a>
       , Baroque poet
       <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Gunduli%C4%87" title="Ivan Gundulić">
        Ivan Gundulić
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatian_national_revival" title="Croatian national revival">
        Croatian national revival
       </a>
       poet
       <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Ma%C5%BEurani%C4%87" title="Ivan Mažuranić">
        Ivan Mažuranić
       </a>
       , novelist, playwright and poet
       <a href="/wiki/August_%C5%A0enoa" title="August Šenoa">
        August Šenoa
       </a>
       , children's writer
       <a href="/wiki/Ivana_Brli%C4%87-Ma%C5%BEurani%C4%87" title="Ivana Brlić-Mažuranić">
        Ivana Brlić-Mažuranić
       </a>
       , writer and journalist
       <a href="/wiki/Marija_Juri%C4%87_Zagorka" title="Marija Jurić Zagorka">
        Marija Jurić Zagorka
       </a>
       , poet and writer
       <a href="/wiki/Antun_Gustav_Mato%C5%A1" title="Antun Gustav Matoš">
        Antun Gustav Matoš
       </a>
       , poet
       <a href="/wiki/Antun_Branko_%C5%A0imi%C4%87" title="Antun Branko Šimić">
        Antun Branko Šimić
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Expressionism" title="Expressionism">
        expressionist
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">
        realist
       </a>
       writer
       <a href="/wiki/Miroslav_Krle%C5%BEa" title="Miroslav Krleža">
        Miroslav Krleža
       </a>
       , poet
       <a href="/wiki/Tin_Ujevi%C4%87" title="Tin Ujević">
        Tin Ujević
       </a>
       and novelist and short story writer
       <a href="/wiki/Ivo_Andri%C4%87" title="Ivo Andrić">
        Ivo Andrić
       </a>
       are often cited as the greatest figures in Croatian literature.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LZMK_249-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LZMK-249">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-Readerguide_250-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYT-Readerguide-250">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
        Media
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Croatia" title="Media of Croatia">
        Media of Croatia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Croatia" title="Cinema of Croatia">
        Cinema of Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The freedom of the press and the freedom of speech are guaranteed by the constitution of Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldpress_251-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-worldpress-251">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia ranked 62nd in the 2010
       <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">
        Press Freedom Index
       </a>
       report compiled by
       <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">
        Reporters Without Borders
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-index_252-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-index-252">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The state-owned news agency
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/HINA" title="HINA">
        HINA
       </a>
       runs a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wire_service" title="Wire service">
        wire service
       </a>
       in Croatian and English on politics, economics, society and culture.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HINA-about_253-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HINA-about-253">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="580" data-file-width="1201" height="106" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg/220px-Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg/330px-Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg/440px-Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Radio Zagreb, now a part of
         <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Radiotelevision" title="Croatian Radiotelevision">
          Croatian Radiotelevision
         </a>
         , was the first public radio station in Southeast Europe.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
          <a href="#cite_note-254">
           [253]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Despite the provisions fixed in the constitution, freedoms of press and speech in Croatia have been classified as partly free since 2000 by
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
        Freedom House
       </a>
       , the independent nongovernmental organisation that monitors press freedom worldwide. Namely the country has been ranked 85th (of 196 countries),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Freedom_of_the_press_255-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Freedom_of_the_press-255">
         [254]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the 2011 Freedom House report noted improvement of applicable legislation reflecting Croatia's accession to the EU, yet pointed out instances of politicians' attempts to hinder
       <a href="/wiki/Investigative_journalism" title="Investigative journalism">
        investigative journalism
       </a>
       and influence news reports contents, difficulties regarding
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_information" title="Freedom of information">
        public access to information
       </a>
       , and that most of print media market is controlled by German-owned
       <a href="/wiki/Hanza_Media" title="Hanza Media">
        Hanza Media
       </a>
       and Austrian-owned
       <a href="/wiki/Styria_Media_Group" title="Styria Media Group">
        Styria Media Group
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
        <a href="#cite_note-256">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">
        Amnesty International
       </a>
       reports that in 2009 in Croatia there was an increase in the number of physical attacks and murders of journalists. The incidents were mainly perpetrated against journalists investigating war crimes and organised crime.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Amnesty_International_257-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Amnesty_International-257">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of October 2011, there are nine nationwide free-to-air DVB-T television channels, with
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Radiotelevision" title="Croatian Radiotelevision">
        Croatian Radiotelevision
       </a>
       (HRT),
       <a href="/wiki/Nova_TV_(Croatia)" title="Nova TV (Croatia)">
        Nova TV
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/RTL_Televizija" title="RTL Televizija">
        RTL Televizija
       </a>
       operating two of the channels each, and the remaining three operated by the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Olympic_Committee" title="Croatian Olympic Committee">
        Croatian Olympic Committee
       </a>
       , Kapital Net d.o.o. and Author d.o.o. companies. In addition there are 21 regional or local DVB-T television channels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OIV-DVBT_258-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-OIV-DVBT-258">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The HRT is also broadcasting a satellite TV channel.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HRT-Sat_259-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HRT-Sat-259">
         [258]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2016, there were 135 radio stations and 25 TV stations in Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia509_260-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia509-260">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cable television and
       <a href="/wiki/IPTV" title="IPTV">
        IPTV
       </a>
       networks are gaining ground in the country, as the cable TV networks already serve 450 thousand people, 10% of the total population of the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lider-IPTV_261-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lider-IPTV-261">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JL-cableTV_262-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-JL-cableTV-262">
         [261]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are 314 newspapers and 2,678 magazines published in Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The print media market is dominated by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Europapress_Holding" title="Europapress Holding">
        Europapress Holding
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Styria_Media_Group" title="Styria Media Group">
        Styria Media Group
       </a>
       who publish their flagship dailies
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Jutarnji_list" title="Jutarnji list">
         Jutarnji list
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Ve%C4%8Dernji_list" title="Večernji list">
         Večernji list
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/24sata_(Croatia)" title="24sata (Croatia)">
         24sata
        </a>
       </i>
       . Other influential newspapers are
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Novi_list" title="Novi list">
         Novi list
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Slobodna_Dalmacija" title="Slobodna Dalmacija">
         Slobodna Dalmacija
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPH-Print_263-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EPH-Print-263">
         [262]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Styria-dailies_264-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Styria-dailies-264">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2013,
       <i>
        24sata
       </i>
       was the most widely circulated daily newspaper, followed by
       <i>
        Večernji list
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Jutarnji list
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
        <a href="#cite_note-265">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Croatia" title="Cinema of Croatia">
        Croatia's film industry
       </a>
       is small and heavily subsidised by the government, mainly through grants approved by the Ministry of Culture with films often being co-produced by HRT.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JL-Film_266-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-JL-Film-266">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HRT-coproducing_267-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HRT-coproducing-267">
         [266]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Pula_Film_Festival" title="Pula Film Festival">
        Pula Film Festival
       </a>
       , the national film awards event held annually in
       <a href="/wiki/Pula" title="Pula">
        Pula
       </a>
       , is the most prestigious film event featuring national and international productions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vjesnik-PulaFilm_268-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Vjesnik-PulaFilm-268">
         [267]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The greatest accomplishment by Croatian filmmakers was achieved by
       <a href="/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Vukoti%C4%87" title="Dušan Vukotić">
        Dušan Vukotić
       </a>
       when he won the 1961
       <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Short_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film">
        Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film
       </a>
       for
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Surogat" title="Surogat">
         Ersatz
        </a>
       </i>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="hr">
         Surogat
        </span>
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vjesnik-surogat_269-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Vjesnik-surogat-269">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_cuisine" title="Croatian cuisine">
        Croatian cuisine
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_wine" title="Croatian wine">
        Croatian wine
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Homar_3.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1021" data-file-width="1581" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Homar_3.jpg/200px-Homar_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Homar_3.jpg/300px-Homar_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Homar_3.jpg/400px-Homar_3.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Homar_3.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Lobster" title="Lobster">
          Lobster
         </a>
         from Dalmatia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fritule(miske).JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Fritule%28miske%29.JPG/200px-Fritule%28miske%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Fritule%28miske%29.JPG/300px-Fritule%28miske%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Fritule%28miske%29.JPG/400px-Fritule%28miske%29.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fritule(miske).JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Fritule" title="Fritule">
          Fritule
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatian traditional cuisine varies from one region to another. Dalmatia and Istria draw upon culinary influences of
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">
        Italian
       </a>
       and other
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cuisine" title="Mediterranean cuisine">
        Mediterranean cuisines
       </a>
       which prominently feature various seafood, cooked vegetables and pasta, as well as condiments such as olive oil and garlic. The continental cuisine is heavily influenced by
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_cuisine" title="Hungarian cuisine">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Austrian_cuisine" title="Austrian cuisine">
        Austrian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">
        Turkish
       </a>
       culinary styles. In that area, meats, freshwater fish and vegetable dishes are predominant.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HTZ-cuisine_270-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HTZ-cuisine-270">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are two distinct wine-producing regions in Croatia. The continental region in the northeast of the country, especially Slavonia, is capable of producing premium wines, particularly whites. Along the north coast, Istrian and Krk wines are similar to those produced in neighbouring Italy, while further south in Dalmatia, Mediterranean-style red wines are the norm.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HTZ-cuisine_270-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-HTZ-cuisine-270">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Annual production of wine exceeds 140 million litres.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Croatia was almost exclusively a wine-consuming country up until the late 18th century when a more massive production and consumption of beer started;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-skenderovic_271-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-skenderovic-271">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the annual consumption of beer in 2008 was 83.3 litres per capita which placed Croatia in 15th place among the world's countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kirin_272-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-kirin-272">
         [271]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Croatia" title="Sport in Croatia">
        Sport in Croatia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:18.10..2015._Arena_._Zagreb_-_panoramio.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="4320" height="73" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/18.10..2015._Arena_._Zagreb_-_panoramio.jpg/350px-18.10..2015._Arena_._Zagreb_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/18.10..2015._Arena_._Zagreb_-_panoramio.jpg/525px-18.10..2015._Arena_._Zagreb_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/18.10..2015._Arena_._Zagreb_-_panoramio.jpg/700px-18.10..2015._Arena_._Zagreb_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="350"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:18.10..2015._Arena_._Zagreb_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Arena_Zagreb" title="Arena Zagreb">
          Arena Zagreb
         </a>
         , one of venues of the
         <a href="/wiki/2009_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2009 World Men's Handball Championship">
          2009 World Men's Handball Championship
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       There are more than 400,000 active sportspeople in Croatia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Perman-400_273-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Perman-400-273">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Out of that number, 277,000 are members of sports associations and nearly 4,000 are members of chess and
       <a href="/wiki/Contract_bridge" title="Contract bridge">
        contract bridge
       </a>
       associations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_87-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-87">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Association football is the most popular sport. The
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Football_Federation" title="Croatian Football Federation">
        Croatian Football Federation
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="hr">
         Hrvatski nogometni savez
        </span>
       </i>
       ), with more than 118,000 registered players, is the largest sporting association in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CFF-members_274-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CFF-members-274">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prva_HNL" title="Prva HNL">
        Prva HNL
       </a>
       football league attracts the highest
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_attendance_figures_at_domestic_professional_sports_leagues" title="List of attendance figures at domestic professional sports leagues">
        average attendance
       </a>
       of any professional sports league in the country. In season 2010–11, it attracted 458,746 spectators.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Index-attendance_275-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Index-attendance-275">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Poljud_panorama_2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="1280" height="75" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Poljud_panorama_2.jpg/200px-Poljud_panorama_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Poljud_panorama_2.jpg/300px-Poljud_panorama_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Poljud_panorama_2.jpg/400px-Poljud_panorama_2.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Poljud_panorama_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poljud" title="Poljud">
          Poljud
         </a>
         stadium,
         <a href="/wiki/Split,_Croatia" title="Split, Croatia">
          Split
         </a>
         was the venue of the
         <a href="/wiki/1990_European_Athletics_Championships" title="1990 European Athletics Championships">
          1990 European Athletics Championships
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Croatian athletes competing at international events since Croatian independence in 1991 won 44
       <a href="/wiki/Croatia_at_the_Olympics" title="Croatia at the Olympics">
        Olympic medals
       </a>
       , including fifteen gold medals—at the
       <a href="/wiki/1996_Summer_Olympics" title="1996 Summer Olympics">
        1996
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics" title="2004 Summer Olympics">
        2004 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Handball" title="Handball">
        handball
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics" title="2000 Summer Olympics">
        2000 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">
        weightlifting
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2002_Winter_Olympics" title="2002 Winter Olympics">
        2002
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics" title="2006 Winter Olympics">
        2006 Winter Olympics
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Alpine_skiing" title="Alpine skiing">
        alpine skiing
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">
        2012 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Discus_throw" title="Discus throw">
        discus throw
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Trap_shooting" title="Trap shooting">
        trap shooting
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Water_polo" title="Water polo">
        water polo
       </a>
       , and in
       <a href="/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics" title="2016 Summer Olympics">
        2016 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shooting_sport" title="Shooting sport">
        shooting
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">
        rowing
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Discus_throw_at_the_Olympics" title="Discus throw at the Olympics">
        discus throw
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sailing_(sport)" title="Sailing (sport)">
        sailing
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Javelin_throw_at_the_Olympics" title="Javelin throw at the Olympics">
        javelin throw
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HOO-medalists_276-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HOO-medalists-276">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition, Croatian athletes won 16 gold medals at world championships, including four in athletics at the World Championships in Athletics held in
       <a href="/wiki/2007_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2007 World Championships in Athletics">
        2007
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2009_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2009 World Championships in Athletics">
        2009
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2013_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2013 World Championships in Athletics">
        2013
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2017_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2017 World Championships in Athletics">
        2017
       </a>
       , one in handball at the
       <a href="/wiki/2003_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2003 World Men's Handball Championship">
        2003 World Men's Handball Championship
       </a>
       , two in water polo at the
       <a href="/wiki/2007_World_Aquatics_Championships" title="2007 World Aquatics Championships">
        2007 World Aquatics Championships
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Water_polo_at_the_2017_World_Aquatics_Championships" title="Water polo at the 2017 World Aquatics Championships">
        2017 World Aquatics Championships
       </a>
       , one in rowing at the
       <a href="/wiki/2010_World_Rowing_Championships" title="2010 World Rowing Championships">
        2010 World Rowing Championships
       </a>
       , six in alpine skiing at the
       <a href="/wiki/FIS_Alpine_World_Ski_Championships_2003" title="FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2003">
        FIS Alpine World Ski Championships held in 2003
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/FIS_Alpine_World_Ski_Championships_2005" title="FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2005">
        2005
       </a>
       and two at the World Taekwondo Championships in
       <a href="/wiki/2011_World_Taekwondo_Championships" title="2011 World Taekwondo Championships">
        2011
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2007_World_Taekwondo_Championships" title="2007 World Taekwondo Championships">
        2007
       </a>
       . Croatian athletes also won the
       <a href="/wiki/2005_Davis_Cup" title="2005 Davis Cup">
        2005 Davis Cup
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Croatia hosted several major sport competitions, including the
       <a href="/wiki/2009_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2009 World Men's Handball Championship">
        2009 World Men's Handball Championship
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/2007_World_Table_Tennis_Championships" title="2007 World Table Tennis Championships">
        2007 World Table Tennis Championships
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/2000_World_Rowing_Championships" title="2000 World Rowing Championships">
        2000 World Rowing Championships
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/1987_Summer_Universiade" title="1987 Summer Universiade">
        1987 Summer Universiade
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/1979_Mediterranean_Games" title="1979 Mediterranean Games">
        1979 Mediterranean Games
       </a>
       and several
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Championship" title="European Championship">
        European Championships
       </a>
       . The governing sports authority in the country is the
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Olympic_Committee" title="Croatian Olympic Committee">
        Croatian Olympic Committee
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="hr">
         Hrvatski olimpijski odbor
        </span>
       </i>
       ), founded on 10 September 1991 and recognised by the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">
        International Olympic Committee
       </a>
       since 17 January 1992, in time to permit the Croatian athletes to appear at the
       <a href="/wiki/1992_Winter_Olympics" title="1992 Winter Olympics">
        1992 Winter Olympics
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Albertville" title="Albertville">
        Albertville
       </a>
       , France representing the newly independent nation for the first time at the
       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">
        Olympic Games
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HOO-COO_277-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HOO-COO-277">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table cellspacing="2" class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="margin-top:7px; margin-right:0; background:none; text-align:center; font-size:90%;">
       <caption>
        Medals won by
        <a href="/wiki/Croatia_at_the_Olympics" title="Croatia at the Olympics">
         Croatia at the Olympics
        </a>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IOCMedalTable_278-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-IOCMedalTable-278">
          [277]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th rowspan="2" style="width:250px;">
         <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">
          Olympic Games
         </a>
        </th>
        <th colspan="3">
         <a href="/wiki/Olympic_medal" title="Olympic medal">
          Olympic medals
         </a>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th style="width:50px;">
         Gold
        </th>
        <th style="width:50px;">
         Silver
        </th>
        <th style="width:50px;">
         Bronze
        </th>
        <th style="width:50px;">
         Total per OG
        </th>
       </tr>
